Drug Dealer Simulator 2 is gonna be crazyyy

If you love fedex style missions in RPGs than this is the "Simulator" for you.  By simulator, they mean first, packaging drugs.  The rest of the simulation... is...  not a simulation.  Since drug dealing in REAL life is so much easier, they made the game take place during a more severe post apocalyptic type time period.  With check points and cops who are truly dumb, not like real life cops.  You can buy all sorts of crap for your various hide outs... but you can't move things from one to another.  You know..... when is the last time you saw a drug dealer moving furniture?  Never.  They just don't do it.  So... that part of the simulation is on point.  The rest....  not so much.  

If you have played House Flipper, DO NOT BE ALARMED.  This is NOT the same game.  Even though it looks like it.  Also... thief simulator...  basically identical.  They likely all used the stock unreal engine for graphics.  

As much as I want to hate on this game I can't.  It has some how pulled me in so that I completely lose my peripheral vision while playing and get the crap scared out of me by my wife.  (In my defence I had just finished running from the cops with a large backpack of drugs and headphones on.)  

Can I recommend the game?  Well....  again only if you really like fedex style missions.  If you, or someone you know, has ever actually dealt drugs and you want to relive that god awful life....  This is not going to be the simulator you are looking for.  But... for 3-4 DOLLARS as it was when I purchased it....  it has been MORE than worth the money.  

I will watch for DDS2 though and hopefully it's more of a simulator than just packaging up drugs and making drops.  I mean...  you provided a bed in the first apt. but we never use it.  We never eat.  We never sleep.  We never use our own supply.  We just...  make deliveries.  day and night.  It's more like...  Robot Drug Dealer Simulator.  Tempt us with women, drugs, booze, games, cars, OH YEAH NO CARS!  Just running on foot constantly.  Yeah... hopefully DDS2 is better.

drug dealing with "Drug Dealer Simulator." Let me tell you, folks, it's been a trip!

First off, let's talk customer service. Ever wanted to make a deal with someone who communicates exclusively in emojis? Well, strap in, because that's just the tip of the iceberg here. From needy junkies to demanding mob bosses, every transaction feels like a high-stakes negotiation...pun intended.

Now, onto the inventory management. Forget about organizing your sock drawer; this game throws you into the thrilling world of drug stockpiles. Ever accidentally mix up your "happy pills" with your "not-so-happy pills"? Yeah, me neither... coughs nervously

But wait, there's more! Who knew running from the cops could be so exhilarating? It's like a game of cat and mouse, except the mouse is a little too fond of hallucinogens. Just remember, kids, crime doesn't pay...unless you're playing a video game, in which case, rack up those virtual dollars!

In conclusion, "Drug Dealer Simulator" delivers an addictive blend of chaos, humor, and questionable life choices. It's like living out your wildest Breaking Bad fantasies without the risk of actual prison time. So grab your balaclava and get ready for a ride you won't soon forget. Just don't forget to pay your virtual bail bondsman on time!

[b][u]April 16th[/u][/b]
Full release for DDS

[b][u]April 18th[/u][/b]
Patch 1: included some bugfixes

[b][u]April 21st[/u][/b]
Patch 2: some more bugfixes

[b][u]April 22nd[/u][/b]
Date of their fourth and final dev livestream where they would catch people up on the game development and answer questions about the game.

[b][u]April 28th[/u][/b]
Patch 1.0.4 (update 3): more bugfixes and a couple of small improvements

[b][u]May 27th[/u][/b]
The long awaited "weed growing" update. A lot of people really liked this update but it didn't fix the fact that there was little to no endgame content.

[strike]One month of them advertising other games from their publisher[/strike]

[b][u]June 26th[/u][/b]
Finally after a month of silence as far as the game itself goes, they mention that the next patch is "just around the corner!"
As for what's included in the patch, the devs say this: [i]"It will include fixes for many common issues, optimization changes, map improvements, and more. One of the new things that we can reveal right now is implementation of the Portuguese and Brazilian Portuguese languages to the game!"[/i]

Another month goes by

[b][u]July 20th[/u][/b]
As it turns out, everything they said would be included in the patch was [i]everything[/i] in the patch. Except even less. It was more bugfixes, a couple of optimizations, and yes, localization for Portuguese and Brazilian Portuguese (according to some Steam users the translations are very bad and don't work well with the UI but I have not used it so I can't verify this). But that's it, there was never any "more". It's been two months and all we get is even more bugfixes which are almost trivial at this point because the game itself is still buggy, unpolished, and generally unfinished, and losing your save is only slightly less common. Players are abandoning the game and getting upset with the devs in the discussions.

[b][u]July 27th[/u][/b]
Announcement for patch 1.0.6 (update 6): The devs open up their community post by saying "The important part is - we are currently 100% back in business and back to the old work paste! First of all - THE GAME HAS NOT BEEN ABANDONED."
Things that will be added in this upcoming patch include -
- UI improvements
- Map improvements
- Graphical remastering
- "Game affecting weather system, including rain and moon phases affecting gameplay"

People are finally fed up with the slow updates and the Steam discussions are as toxic as a nuclear meltdown inside a volcano of green sludge.

One user accuses the devs of abusing their power on Discord, although I've seen no one else talk about this and I've never been there myself so take it with a grain of salt.
[quote=darklight] the only place to get any real info is in their discord. though on there is a very cliquey group who like to attack everyone and everything like a room filled with trolls. and the admins are power hungry zealots that will throw their power around at random to get a kick or get a laugh. its [truly] the most toxic discord group ive ever had the displeasure of being in.

if you can stand being in there and if you happen to be around when a mod or a dev speaks about the plans for the game you might [hear] some news.

its the worst setup ive seen coming from a "professional" company.

so far they have made so many poor choices that putting main game elements behind a paywall wouldnt surprise me. they have been uncommunicative and lackluster so far so why expect different in the future,
[/quote]

[b][u]July 30th[/u][/b]
Devs release a devlog this time not in the form of a stream, but in a [i]slightly[/i] more organized video format. The lead developer opens the video by acknowledging the fact that they were quiet for such a long time and explains that this period of inactivity was due to office renovations and the fact that they were recruiting a lot of new people to their team. For the rest of the video he goes more in depth showing what they're working on for the next patch and admittedly it looks better than they made it sound on paper.
------------------------------------------------

          So that's the timeline of the game since it's launch. My conclusion is that Byterunners are a [u]very[/u] inexperienced team who don't really know how to prioritize their workload (working on graphical improvements while the community begs for more end-game content). Do I think the game is abandoned? [b]Certainly not[/b]. Do I think it will it take a [u]long[/u] time before the game is actually worth $20 or even sitting down to play for longer than 30 mins? [b]Definitely[/b].
          Give the game some time, like, a lot of time. Add it to your wishlist and check on it every few months or so. It's got potential for sure, and I still think the devs are hard at work, they're just not good at working efficiently.




Game is actually in a pretty decent state now, lots of end-game content, worth the $20.

I bought the game on sale and at first I've become addicted to it, trying to learn the game and all. However, after I've built my first house - there was no point to play anymore. The game is quite repetitive -  create mix, split it, deliver. Go home, read the messages, collect the money, take new orders. Go water the plants, go deliver. And those dumb checkpoints.
After a while, there's nothing left to do - if I wanted to decorate my imaginary house, I'd play SIMS. 
So yes, first part of the game, can bu fun. But "end game" sucks and no point in playing the game after.
Now, since I bought it on sale and I've put 100+ hours playing it - I'll give it a pass.
But it's not worth the full price. I'd like to see some turf war or something.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead‚Äì murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time ‚Äì something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange ‚Äì uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" ‚Äì on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

Very enjoyable game to play when you find yourself bored. It can become repetitive but there is always something new every time you level up. On my first campaign I didn't save and the game crashed (luckily early on). On my second campaign I hadn't saved the game for 20 minutes and then it crashed again. Unfortunately, this time I had progressed pretty far into the game and my last save was a game day old. I personally hate going backwards in progression after completing a whole bunch of in-game tasks (this made me want to smash my PC). My PC can run games 20X the size of DDS on full graphics without crashing but for some reason my PC can't handle this? Mixed review, the idea of the game is good and could be expanded with the right developers. Very fun game to kill time on, just unfortunate the game has many technical issues. I might play this game again in the future but for now it's staying in my game library.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Exactly what it says on the tin. It's also, ironically enough, pretty addicting. Something about the micromanaging of a small time street dealer's routine and working all the way up to commanding an empire of illicit substances is both satisfying and a lot of fun.

It really feels like the renaissance of old cringey drug games on Newgrounds. Your narrator/player character sounds like the Postal Guy and says everything like he's reading the tagline for a D-list action movie. The world of DDS is unapologetically over the top and campy, but it adds a level of charm that the game benefits from.

Tl;dr should you buy this game at full price? Oh god no, not in a million years. Is it worth picking up on sale? If you like simulator games and the thought of producing and dealing in a ghetto, by all means, but I'd recommend waiting for it to drop under $5.

The low points:
- The controls. Breaking it down to brass tacks, this is a pretty janky UE4 game. It can be fun, but it can also break extremely easily. This game has an interesting relationship with the mouse and UI, because it'll only successfully work about 70% of the time. The other 30%, you're stuck doing the same action over and over again trying to get a response. Could it be worse? Sure, but it doesn't take away from the frustration.
- The GPU usage. It's gonna be using 100% of your GPU the entire time you're playing. This may be a minor issue for some people, but it may be a deal breaker for others.

The high points:
- The ways that this game delivers on its campy premise in spades. You use an app on your laptop to organize the buying and/or selling of your products, then you either go to meet with your clients to sell or find a dead drop to pick up your product respectfully.  
You use graffiti to tag up different neighborhoods and gain respect/expand your influence. It's a nice break from the cycle of buying/selling and lets you indulge more in the criminal aspects of the game. You can use your money to expand your operations, buying other properties, new products, customizing the properties you have, or paying for graffiti and other tools of the trade. You can also expand to the point of hiring your own dealers and running your own growing and money laundering operations. 

Again, if that sounds like fun to you and would enjoy the micromanaging involved in a street crime simulator, then by all means, I'd recommend this game (again, on sale- $20 is a pretty steep price for this.) Otherwise, there's no shame in skipping this one.

So this isn't the best game. It's not even really good, but still, I recommend it. Why? It's a clunky game with a simple gameplay loop that oversells itself and under-delivers on the promised flash. So why would I play it for 100+ hours? Because under the clunk, there's fun to be had. The game has some techniques you can learn with the movement to really fly and get around the obstacles, you can spend hours in fiddly menus, and if you line up a long chain of deliveries to complete, you're really under the gun to keep things running fast and smooth. It's not really a "movie game", more of a task completion simulator, but if that's your jam then you'll enjoy completing the tasks you're presented with.

DDS is actually not a bad game now that it is the full version of the game and no longer a work in progress, although there is a lot of content that was shown in the original trailers for this game that never actually made it into the game sadly. But even so this is still a pretty good game and it can be pretty addicting. for 20$ i feel now that the game is finished it is worth it. The biggest con about this game i would say is how long it can take to grind things out when first starting out, but the game will and does pick up more and more with every few levels gain. Unfortunately there is A LOT of running back and forth but honestly i get it since you are a drug dealer so you would be doing a lot of travel back and forth to people, i just wish there was some other way of travel other than just running on foot everywhere, like maybe a bike or a moped. There has been a lot of good things added into the game that it really needed since it was first released, like you can now get a mansion once you build up your drug empire and become wealthy enough to afford it. Although one thing never really made much sense to me about the mansion, it's location is in a slums type area, this just feels odd and does not make a lot of sense, i honestly feel like the mansion should have been placed in a higher class type area that could have been added onto the map. Overall for a smaller dev team i think they did a pretty good job with the game.

I came across this game at random on Steam and it was on a massive sale so I got it for $1.50. But it is worth far more. If you ever played the simplistic dope wars game, and found it fun then this will blow your mind. Think real world simulator as a drug dealer. Buy pure product cut it and experiment with additives and mixing drugs to create your own unique products. Too poisonous or addictive you get ODs, get the amount of addictive substances right you get addicts who pay more, satisfy a client enough they become a dealer. Oh and then the cops and the state, cop are everywhere and looking suspicious will draw a search. There is a curfew as well, so avoiding the cops is pretty much a top priority. And if you deposit too much illicit cash, well the state will draw interest. So you better find a way to launder that cash! All in all it is a simple game, buy drugs, sell them for a profit, and expand your empire. But at the same time it is a fully engaging game that can totally capture your attention and interest.

I thought at first that this game would be just another asset flip. I got it to spend a couple of hours and uninstall. But, honestly, it's a great game and the devs continue to update it and add content. It was fun when I first got it and they have only added to it. They truly listen to their players and add things that the community wants. Don't let the outdated graphics fool you. This game is engaging and fun to play and makes you feel like you're a part of the world and actually advancing and generating wealth. It teaches you everything you need to know to play and you'll advance at a reasonable pace. You won't be confused like most games that are overcomplicated and don't explain things. I gauge value based on dollars spent per hours played and I absolutely believe I got my money's worth. With all the new content, I see myself downloading the game again and exploring all the new features.

Drug Dealer Simulator - Exploring the Dark Side of the Criminal World

[Introduction]

"Drug Dealer Simulator" is a simulation game developed by Byterunners Game Studio. In this game, players immerse themselves in the dangerous world of the underground by engaging in drug trade. The game offers a realistic drug business simulation, allowing players to explore the criminal underworld.

[Story]

While the game lacks a traditional story campaign, players have the freedom to craft their own narratives in the drug trade business. The game presents various tasks and challenges, expecting players to carve their own path in the criminal world.

[Gameplay]

"Drug Dealer Simulator" focuses on drug production, distribution, and trade. Players can produce drugs, sell them to customers, make a profit, and expand their operations. However, they must also deal with the police and rival gangs. The gameplay is realistic and requires players to make risky decisions.

[Graphics and Sounds]

"Drug Dealer Simulator" successfully captures the gritty and dangerous atmosphere of the criminal underworld through its graphics and sounds. Dark streets, drug labs, and character designs immerse players in the criminal world. The sound design enhances the atmosphere with police radio chatter, street noise, and other details, adding to the realism.

[Conclusion]

"Drug Dealer Simulator" offers an intriguing experience for players interested in exploring the dangers of the criminal world and the complexities of the drug trade. Realistic gameplay, tough decisions, and the intricacies of the criminal underworld make the game appealing. However, please note that the game contains themes and content related to crime, so age restrictions should be considered.

Rating: 7/10

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead‚Äì murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time ‚Äì something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange ‚Äì uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" ‚Äì on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

It is very monotonous and pretty grindy. For the most part you are running or sneaking around the map, trying to deliver the goods without being caught by the police. It might be thrilling early on, but after a while it gets a bit stale.

After playing for over 230 hours, I'm left with a bitter-sweet mixed feeling. I still give this a thumbs up, because it's not a bad game and I did have my fair share of fun. I just wish there were more depth to it than running around as a delivery boy. 

So, before you buy this, try the demo! If you like it, then it might actually be worth it. If it's on sale then it definitely is!


GOOD
- Currently the only good game of its genre ("Weed Shop 3" doesn't count, that's a legal grow/dispensary sim. It's good though, but maybe even more grindy than DDS).
- Mix/make your own stuff using functional lab equipment. Just remember that your customers demands a certain level of quality and a bad product can kill them. So be careful what you mix and how much.
- You can use the products and observe its effects on your character. Hint: [spoiler] Some might be very beneficial. [/spoiler]
- Recruit dealers and sell larger quantities.
- Several buildings are for rent, which you can use as hideouts or set up as a lab and assign crew.
- You can buy villas and decorate them, but they are very expensive!
- OK, but not great, selection of furniture and decoration for your hideouts/labs/villas.
- Good in-game music (it's a shame that you can't buy a stereo/radio for your hideouts).

NEUTRAL
- No vehicles or guns.
- Can't go inside "Two Towers", the party building.

BAD
- Making money and progression is grindy!
- Sneaking around the police, gets boring after a while.
- The way the police is patrolling the streets is unrealistic. They will almost always stop and search you if your in their near vicinity.
- Police hours between 21:00 and 07:00, which means people are not allowed to be outside. You will be arrested even if you don't carry anything illegal. I get why this was implemented ([spoiler] customers pays more and your activity is less noticed [/spoiler]), but it's kinda dumb. Police doesn't have any issue with everyone else walking around.
- City is split up into three regions. Each time you travel to another region you must pass through a police post at the border which means they will stop and search you. There are other secret ways to travel between the regions, like [spoiler] the sewer [/spoiler], but it requires frequent lockpicking and after a while just feels like a chore.
- Lab UI is not especially user-friendly and makes everything very tedious, even the simplest task as splitting your products for your customers. It's a bit of a learning curve for new players, but not the worst I've seen in games.
- City feels dead and lifeless, partly by the fact that there's no traffic but also because there's few NPCs walking around. They also act kinda robotic.
- Lockpicking. You have to lockpick the same locks over and over again, since they automatically lock after some time. I really wish there were a lockpicking skill, making it faster and easier to lockpick later in game.
- Police chatter (mainly there for you to hear the police coming) goes like this "......, OVER!". Nobody uses the closure phrase "over", that's from way back in stone-age times. It might not sound like a big deal, but after 230h+ it becomes very annoying, especially when they sometimes camp right outside your hideout while you're trying to do some cutting/mixing work.
- Map size is fairly small.
- Story is a bit short. It's just ends way too early. After the story ends, you haven't exactly finished the game, but you now have to find your own motivation to continue playing. Either it be achievements, the villas or whatever.

Play the demo and/or buy it on sale. It's a good game, however it leaves MUCH to be desired. It had the potential to be the greatest drug dealing/criminal lifestyle simulator but just falls short.

Pros:

[list]
[*] The map is amazing - a huge rundown, segregated neighbourhood, truly makes you feel like you're in "the right place" to sell drugs;
[*] Fairly decent police system - the more reckless you are when selling your goods, the more police attention you'll get - forcing you to manage your playstyle accordingly;
[*] Up to nine different drugs and ten secondary ingredients which you can use to create your own mix;
[*] The storyline/lore is quite interesting and compels you to play further;
[*] The gameplay in general is pretty entertaining
[/list]

Cons:

[list]
[*] Occasionally it feels like the map is TOO big, which can be frustrating at times;
[*] Once you get used to it, the police system is nothing but a nuisance to you. Excluding what happens in the storyline, it is also the only type of adversity you'll find in the game - no rival dealers, gangs, snitches, traitors, undercover cops, nothing. The dangers and unpredictabilities of being a drug dealer is simply not there. This is IMO one of the biggest flaws with the game.
[*] The drug managing/mixing system is awful, especially due to the randomness of the clients' orders, this can be really frustrating for many players.
[*] The storyline feels more like a backdrop, a secondary element to the game, and while it is compelling, it also feels rushed and not very well-polished.
[*] While the gameplay is entertaining in general, it is only for the first few hours of gameplay, or at most until you finish the storyline. After doing so, the game just feels repetitive and eventually it gets boring.
[/list]

Sadly, it feels like the cons outweight the pros in this game. It appears the devs focused too much on the namesake of the game, which just results in a cycle of:

[olist]
[*] Obtain drugs
[*] Get clients' orders
[*] Sell drugs while avoiding police
[*] Repeat
[/olist]

Combine this cycle with the cons and you'll find this game leaves much to be desired. The game is true to its name, you can sell drugs to your heart's content, but eventually you'll just grow tired and bored of it, similar to your 9-5 job.
Hands down the most boring, repetitive, least inventive game I have ever played.

I'd like to give this game a good review, it's quite fun, but there's just a few large and otherwise glaring issues that stop it from being a good game. 

Good stuff first: Gameplay loop is easy to understand, sometimes hard to execute, which leads to simple but enjoyable gameplay. Pretty simple shit. Order product, pick up product, portion out product based on who wants what, take that product to people, pay your suppliers, order more, repeat. Throw in a cop or two here and there, or maybe curfew is on, and it's great. A few high speed chases perhaps, some adrenaline, feelings of satisfaction sneaking around like a dope ninja... all good stuff. 

There's some halfway decent humor and otherwise strong messages to be had in this game, and the environment is, if not stellar, than not the absolute worst I've seen. Still pretty bad, and the animations could use some work, perhaps. A bit moving or "shocking" here or there (Looking at you, Stoned bee which made me jump) but those are most certainly not what you're playing this one for.

Progression is slow, but that's seemingly by design. Can't be a drug lord in 15 minutes or less, it takes some time and skill. Unlocking things like growing your own product, being able to sell new products, and moving through checkpoints, great, love it. Feels good. 

Now on to the stuff I really don't understand or like:

Mouse smoothing / acceleration. It's not 2010. I am not playing with a trackpad. I have no interest in having my character spin like one of those flying fairy toys that get sucked into fireplaces. Fix this shit. Which leads to the next point:

Devs are pretty dismissive of criticism, as one would expect from a team behind this quality of game. To the point where it seems like they just don't care. I would say this game isn't dead, more like on life support. Devs push maybe part of a feature, maybe something small, something that wouldn't take more than a little while to develop, and make it a full update. The game's not dead only because development is a crawl. Sure, some new features are out and they're okay, but a lot has been promised, either in trailers or concepts, and not much has been delivered. On the topic of those new features...

Optimization. There is none, hasn't been for a long time now. Of course, making features work would take away from the budget for new things being added, and fixing things is a hell of a lot less interesting when you can lure people in with new things, no matter if it breaks everything and your framerate is capped at about 30-45 frames for long periods of time, only to return to normal for a few minutes and then dive again. Sorry if that's a bit harsh, but there's absolutely no passion put into the whole process, I feel. It feels like a scam, but hey, the gameplay is just okay enough for me to say it's probably not, maybe. 

Overall, if you're bored or you see this game on sale and you'd really like to try it, there's always the free demo, and I'd advise trying the "Free Sample" first. If you like it, great. It's not great, not utterly abysmal, just okay, but not really worth the rating of Thumbs Up for steam, kinda right in the middle. The mouse smoothing thing puts in into the negative cause I feel like I want to vomit. At least you can adjust motion blur.
8/10 Just a little buggy around the edges, but it's a lot of fun.

Drug Dealer Simulator is a unique indie game I would highly recommend for people who are looking for something different.

Negatives:

Let's get the obvious out of the way first: DDS is a debut indie game. Not only did the devs have to do without a AAA budget, but they also learned by doing. And while the devs listened to feedback from fans, implementing most suggestions would‚Äôve required a complete overhaul of the game. So many of these suggestions were incorporated into the development of DDS2. 

As such, if you‚Äôve bought DDS2 and are here to see where it all began, be aware that many of the features you probably take for granted aren‚Äôt here.

You will do most tasks yourself, manually. So be prepared for repetition and tedium.

The tutorials are spotty‚Äîespecially when it comes to mixing product. Each product is different, and you WILL NEED GUIDES to help you not OD clients. Even a few in game lines of dialogue to walk you through your first mix would‚Äôve been INSANELY helpful. And when it comes to things like addiction mixes, premixes, gang mixes‚Ä¶ Well, I‚Äôm beating the drum kind of hard, but you get the idea. Mixing product is a science, and neither I nor the MC voice-over remember high school chemistry class.

The same thing goes for the quests. There isn‚Äôt any hand holding. Again, even a few in-game lines of dialogue‚ÄîLike, on the Psychedelics mission: ‚ÄúHey, what‚Äôs that candle doing there? That could be the signal. Go on, check it out! The message has to be in a container somewhere.‚Äù--would‚Äôve helped. And I mean a lot. Again, check the DISCUSSIONS tab on the Community Hub for quest guides. You. Will. Need. Them.

And the AI spotting for the police can be downright off. Sometimes, cops won‚Äôt be able to see you close to them. Other times, they will spot you through the 3 inch sliver between the two buildings you were hiding behind. 

Positives:

STORY: DDS is a game that defied convention. Where the boldness of the devs was joined by a player base that wouldn‚Äôt let YouTube demonetization and social stigma keep us from sharing the game with others. And that shines through starting with the concept. The story isn‚Äôt ham-fisted‚Äîwe get just enough to justify TRAPs and why there are no weapons, sector lock downs, and curfews. But I hope the social situation with TRAPS is explored more in future sequels, and how these events affected people who will likely need our product to cope.

As for the game, you go from small fry to running the show‚Äîand who doesn‚Äôt love that?

MIXING: Yes, there is a trick to mixing. But making your own mix is awesome and something I find enjoyable. Moreover it really reflects your personality: Are you a perfectionist who goes for quick addiction mixes, then cheap addict mixes to maximize profit? Are you a poison peddler looking to cause trouble? Or are you the one who knocks on that and makes the purest, safest universal mix knowing that clients will (eventually) get hooked on a quality product, and forever remember your name?

SELLING: To be honest, this is the experience that I bought the game to simulate. Meeting clients, making the sales, allying with dealers, setting prices‚ÄîDealing is literally the name of the game.

TL;DR

I thoroughly enjoyed the game and, as of writing this review, I am eagerly awaiting the sequel to get my next fix.

[h1] Drugs are bad, mmkay?  [/h1] 

It's pretty much like every other simulator in that it's repetitive (naturally) except that there's a whole lot more going on to the point of it being overwhelming, in my opinion. It's a game where you really need to use 110% of your brain, be 110% efficient, plan ahead, strategize, micromanage and deal with dozen different things all at once. You should also be somewhat good at maths. Absolutely not a chill game but maybe you're into that. 

You've got to make sure you're keeping a low profile, that you're always stocked up on all the different products, find the time to cut/stretch/mix, prep and organise everything, deal with your dealers/clients (clients have a time limit), keep reputations high in a dozen different areas, hopefully not forget to water your weed, smuggle the products from one sector to another, hopefully not get lost in the sewers, avoid the police, tag and/or give out free samples to boost rep/attract new clients and then after all that give the cartel all your money (debt), etc. There's a lot to deal with.

Personally, I found a notebook and pen handy to have on hand while playing for writing down recipes/mixes and such. 

A lot of things are tedious/time consuming and just plain annoying for the sake of being annoying, like the time it takes to be searched, tag, refill water bottles, search garbage for loot for laundering, etc. The devs also seem to go out of their way to [i] fix [/i] "exploits" like parkouring in order to move from one sector to another. I guess they want you to use the sewers which are difficult to navigate and easy to get lost in - lots of dead ends and locked gates (p.s. This game has the worst lockpicking I've ever had to deal with). I'm not sure why though - why does it matter if a player chooses to be more creative in moving around the map and playing the game?

Luckily, there are a few mods on the Nexus that can eliminate many elements which you might not like, e.g. the reputation degradation (I found that by removing that, it made the game a whole lot more chill and I was able to relax, take my time and focus on what I wanted to). After all, druggies shouldn't be so demanding and I'd say in reality it doesn't work like that. A lot of QoL mods there too - I must've installed about 5-6 mods all at once by the time I'd ran out of patience. Trust me, you'll simply be saving yourself hours of time and/or make the game actually playable and to your liking.

I find the gameplay is quite addictive - ha, get it? Cos like drugs? Okay... The spooky sewers and night ambience, stealth and sneaking about, evading police or getting chased by them is really fun - adrenaline! The whole process of getting the products and organising them and/or mixing with additives like baking soda, sugar, painkillers, etc, is fun. Experimenting and pretty much making/naming your own product, making the deliveries and slowly working through the story. There is a feeling of progression from small fry to boss man and becoming somewhat more self sufficient - feels good. Your inner monologue (the narrator) is pretty cool and kind of sounds like Postal Dude.

Repetitive, tedious, big learning curve, awkward at times and feels like work sometimes (especially without mods) but there's definitely plenty of fun and satisfaction to be had and room for a bit of imagination.

Drug Dealer Simulator - Where Sewers Are the New Five-Star Hideaways!

Rogue Rating ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (4/5) 

Ladies and gentlemen, brace yourselves because Drug Dealer Simulator is here, and it's more addictive than grandma's secret cookie recipe! I'm awarding it a Rogue Rating of four out of five trench coats because, let's face it, where else can you become a criminal mastermind hiding in sewers from the fashionably late police?

This game takes you on a rollercoaster ride through the criminal underworld, and trust me, it's a wild one. You'll start as a small-time dealer peddling products that wouldn't impress a goldfish. But with the right connections and some street smarts, you'll be pushing more stuff than a salesman on Black Friday.

Now, let's talk about the sewers. In Drug Dealer Simulator, they're like your secret getaway spots, your Batcave if you will. When the fuzz is hot on your heels, you'll find yourself crawling through the muck and mire like a ninja on vacation. It's a hide-and-seek game where the stakes are higher than a giraffe's basketball match.

The graphics in the game make you feel like you've stepped into a gritty crime drama. The mean streets are meaner than your aunt's cat, and the neon lights give the place an ambiance that says, "Welcome to the danger zone." And speaking of danger, don't forget to check your corners when you're sprinting through dark alleyways; you never know what's lurking in the shadows.

Managing your drug empire is like trying to organize a bake sale in a prison cafeteria. You'll need to keep track of your inventory, avoid undercover cops, and make deals with the shadiest characters this side of the Mississippi. It's a balancing act that makes juggling flaming chainsaws look easy.

As for the community, it's a mix of seasoned crime lords and newcomers who probably shouldn't quit their day jobs just yet. You'll find tips on evading the law, tales of epic getaways, and debates on whether pineapple belongs on pizza (because why not?).

In conclusion, Drug Dealer Simulator is a hilarious and intense ride through the seedy underbelly of the criminal world. If you've ever wondered what it's like to be the ultimate hustler, this game will give you a taste. Just remember, in the world of drug dealing, the sewers are your sanctuaries, and the police are your personal party crashers. Enjoy the thrill, but keep your nose clean, metaphorically speaking!

JULY 2023 UPDATE:
after THREE (3) YEARS i found a fix. what'd i do was about every month i'd reinstall the game and see if it would ran and the same thing i previously stated would happen. well, i finally found a fix. after 3 years, turns out this game has an issue with processors like mine (i7-11700kf) & you have to press WIN+R & type in "SystemPropertiesAdvanced" and tweak with your system variables. Yea, after 3 years, it was that simple. I look like a fool. So, I go back into the game that was so beloved to me at the time. Is it the same? Has the game been changed at all?

(by the way if you are facing that same issue and think what i did would fix it here's a guide: https://support.gog.com/hc/en-us/articles/360019775837?product=gog) 

For the record, I used to be an official beta tester for this game. So I know all about all the suggestions that was suggested at the time (including bugs that needed to be patched). When are psychedelics going to get added? Will you make the game harder? When is there going to be an ending? The map is too small, when will you add more places to go to? When will there be drug labs? Drug use? Can we grow marijuana plants? Will you add money laundering? GUNS!? Well, I'll dive into this.

-> Looks like most of the bugs that the game used to suffer from has been fixed. I've experienced minor bugs but it's nothing game breaking or detrimental. 

-> Psychedelics have been added to the game. You have to go through some hoops to unlock them (which keeps things interesting instead of just unlocking them through your laptop). 

-> Game has been made harder. I've noticed exposition (factor that controls how much police are on the streets and if the DEA is tracking you) has been tweaked with. You can't just deposit money in your ATM at night anymore (which used to basically give you no exposition). You have to go to hideouts and give a shady man your money and he'll launder it for you. The manholes/sewers has been tweaked with. You used to be able to just enter a sewer near the market and it'd automatically teleport you to Sector B. This was a problem because police would patrol right over that manhole so if you spawned at the wrong time you were screwed. Now there's an entire maze of a sewer you can access, with gates that need to be pick-locked to access more of it. You can also peak out of manholes so you don't just spawn right on top of a police officer. There's now also more police checkpoints. There used to be only 3 checkpoints: at all three entrance ways to Sector B from Sector A. Now, at night time, random police checkpoints will spawn on the street with two police officers watching each side, making you take alternative routes. It also seems like the police are more dedicated to chase you & have a larger field of vision. And the perk that gives you a percent chance of being searched with drugs on you and them not being found seems to have been nerfed. I remember just walking through multiple checkpoints and my drugs not being found. I ran an experiment where I saved with a gram of drugs on me and went through a checkpoint and they were found all 10 times (even though 1 time it said I was caught during police hours even though it was noon). The duffel bag has also been nerfed. You used to be able to throw the duffel bag across the Sector A/B wall with ease, now it's basically impossible without doing all the mathematics and getting your trajectory right. You also used to be able to just put a bunch of drugs in a duffel bag, take the one manhole to Sector B, and then hide a bunch of kilos in the warehouse near the Sector B manhole. Now, duffels seem to be kind of useless and you can't enter the sewer with one on. You can wear a different backpack and place a full duffel bag in the separate backpack, though. By the way not hating on any of these changes, makes the game harder & less repetitive. 

-> An ending has in fact been added. No spoilers though.

-> Old news but you can in fact grow marijuana :) My game started experiencing the not starting issue within a week of this update happening like 3 years ago, lol. 

-> Map has been increased. It used to be just Sector A and Sector B. Now you got Sector C (basically Sector B but harder to access) & a camp on the border of the map in Sector A.

-> Drug labs have been added (at least from what I've read). I for some reason can't access them even though I fit all the requirements but I'll end up figuring it out. 

-> From what I've noticed you can't use the drugs you make (at least from any obvious menus, I've been focused on selling them!). But there does seem to be a health system that I never noticed before. If you go below a certain amount of health, your screen will start acting like a drunken bastard and you'll walk slower. 

-> Still no guns but in my own personal opinion it would be a very unnecessary part of the game. But I remember everyone asking for it back then so that's why I included it lol. 

-> There's a lot more hideouts to rent & you can even build whole houses once you complete the game.

-> They've also finally added achievements to the game! Looks like I can officially 100% drug dealing.

The only problem I've experienced is the fact that La Ballerina (or however you spell their name) won't give me any more trafficking missions besides the first one, but I think that has something to do with not having a drug lab. Maybe it'll take me 3 years to figure that out, who knows?

Anyway, Looks like this game has improved a lot from when it was first released. Really proud of the developers for what they've accomplished. And now they're making a sequel? I'll definitely be checking that out when it releases.

If you are thinking about getting this game I'd recommend it. It's a really fun game that's kind of addicting if you get way too into it (the grind of selling so little to having to balance having multiple dealers & your own clientele all in different places of the map which have certain requirements to access and different levels of patience).

Edited review, STILL negative years later.
IN SHORT;
Do not buy for anything $10 or less, it's a tycoon game that is not what was originally advertised.

IN NOT-SO-SHORT;
The original trailer for the game existed, of course, before the game's release date (THE trailer that got everyone to buy it off release) was taken down a few months after the release because of how inaccurate it was. It featured guns, rooftop escapes from DEA, some other mechanics that I don't personally care for, etc. 
- All mentioned are still not in the game to this day, 3 and a half years after release. I believe you can still find this trailer on YT but only by people who have reposted it; the original channel (PlayWay), as I said, removed it.

The developer's response to negative reviews are ridiculous and always consist of 

"sorry you didn't like it, we didn't do (thing in the trailer) because we didn't want the game to be like GTA (or some other thing). With the next updates I'm sure we'll see you back on the streets :D" 

You'd be surprised at how many replies seem to be the EXACT same. And then the fan base will take some more acid and reply with the somewhat same exact zombie message as any other delinquent;

"DDS is made by foreign indie devs... you're an idiot to expect a perfect game lmao go play GTA"

If anyone reading this has played Ready Or Not, you'll know that their fanbase consists of the same zombies; complain about the product (which the consumer has the right to do) and you get multiple replies claiming everything is a "skill issue" and be told to "relax" because they're "indie devs" and/or be told to "go play a different game".

To this day there are spelling errors in the game (which I don't mind because it's not at all game-breaking and easily read-through) but the problem is the AGE of the game AND THE FACT THAT THEY'RE MAKING ANOTHER ONE... That's right; Drug Dealer Simulator 2 - "We gave up on the first game so let's make another one only to eventually make the same mistakes". 

Pretty much, if you're tight on money, avoid anything from PlayWay, Movie Games, or Byterunner. They make, produce, or launch the same crap, mostly low effort "simulator" genre games.

Now, yes, you will see that I have over a hundred hours of play time... and after I post this there will be even more hours coming along; the reason for this is simple; ALL media (movies, tv shows, video games, etc) is boring; nothing is entertaining anymore. It ends up being the same cyclical system where I get really into one of the same 5 things and go replay the same few games... 

Interested in police, I go play Ready or Not and FiveM.
Interested in military, I go play Ground Branch, Six Days in Fallujah, and Ghost Recon.
Interested in survival, I go play Project Zomboid, Stranded Deep, and Green Hell.
Interested in violent crime, I go play GTA, RDR2, and Payday.

The cycle never ends... until it does. So, anyway, that's why you'll see I have more hours after this negative review; currently I'm back into a "breaking bad" phase so expect more hours coming soon.

Played it since the release pretty much.
Always came back to it nearly every half year for a long while. I have no idea why it is so addicting about it  (probably drugs), but the gameplay loop is extremely fun. 
With all the updates you have a lot on your plate to play with and to work for, but i have to admit that the more and more clients you get the more and more annoying it becomes also. 
You can't have 5 minutes for yourself without clients bugging you for chumpchange deliveries. No way to lower the requests from clients nor can you actually shut down a sector if you do not want to deliver to it anymore.

Would be so much better if clients later on would actually be able to come to you instead. I know it is the intended gameplay to find ways around police and gates, but after doing it 500 times it gets just annoying and tedious, if you never ever really have anything on you, yet still have to be searched every single time you pass the gates.

Maybe implement some kind of "trust" system. The more and more police can't find anything on you, the more there is a chance that they just let you pass the gates without searching you. That or actually implement a feature to bribe police for a day not to look at you. 

Also the tunnel you can use in early game is the most useless feature i have ever seen later on, since he just asks for more and more money to pass the ventshafts. Seriously? 350 and more just to quickly pass it? 
Yeah of course you later on make so much money that you don't really give a shit about it anymore, but it is about early to midgame where it could have been an actual alternative to be used. Like this it is just utterly useless at the beginning and neglectable in lategame.

Also you should have added some creature comforts. Cook-Book that automatically applies recipes and adds ingredients for you. Even could have been some device you have to buy later on. Would have been a QoL upgrade you don't need but will love to have if you can afford it.

Oh well.
If you are into the idea to play a dealer and have a bit of an insight behind the scenes of some illegal activities like that, i can absolutely recommend the game.

Drug Dealer Simulator is a game about, well, being a drug dealer. when i heard about this on realise i watched the development every now and again. eager to give this a try. now that i have put 40 hours into the game and done the main story. i'd say its not really worth it for FULL PRICE. if its on offer then maybe.

-Pick up dropoff of your ordered drugs
-Check Orders
-Get the drugs and how much to the exact gram
-Sell it to each person.
-Repeat steps 2 thru to 5 until you need a refil
-Call up the cartel to give you more shit
-And repeat.

thats the whole gameplay loop for about 70% of the game. and i cant really tell if its fun or not. if you look at the advertised game then the game itself your going to be wildly let down. The game really does feel like that. Although im not talking to highly about this game or what its like. i myself havent or cant remember  any truly bad or gamebreaking bugs. but that might just be me. 

In short for all you goblins who cant read. Get it on offer. boring-ish gameplay loop. and not what was advertised at launch.

First off, Drug Dealer Simulator (or DDS, as it's known) is an incredibly fun game. Is it slightly clunky, especially if you just aren't used to the controls at first, or, like me, you foolishly tried to play this on a controller by mapping all movement actions (jump, sprint, crouch, etc.) to a single button? Yes. That clunkiness fades about 5-6 hours in, and then you're packaging illicit substances like it's Pablo Escobar's factories and dodging cops better than Sam Lake posting about his escape from Christchurch law enforcement on Facebook.
Now another warning: the graphics for DDS are not magic, super-slick new-CoD-release, AAA-game-studio stuff. It's sorta like the stuff from the late '00s and early '10s, when things looked pretty realistic but not so realistic that you can fool news stations with screenshots from RDR2. Trust me, this is an endearing feature. It fits with the timeline: the rise of small-time drug dealers, your best friends, the weird guy from high school, that neighbor who seems to be coming and going at all hours, your work bestie? They can all be dealers for you in this game, even the lady in a power suit who's really just a highly-paid secretary.
OH, and there's story in this game. No, this isn't just some bum ass "simulator" game that's "oddly satisfying" but also probably not worth the money (looking at you, Powerwash Simulator and Food Truck Simulator). Yeah. Keep an eye on the neighbors. Someone just might be a DEA agent looking to nail you to the broadside of a barn for possession with intent to distribute, or even RICO.
Oh, and by the way, if you see the black van... keep your head on a swivel. It just might save your life.

Introduction:
Drug Dealer Simulator is a captivating virtual adventure that takes players on an adrenaline-fueled journey into the gritty underworld of illicit drug trade. Developed by skilled creators, this game offers a unique and immersive experience, blending elements of simulation, strategy, and storytelling. As a player, you will find yourself engrossed in a thrilling world of crime, making crucial decisions and navigating the consequences of your actions. Let's dive into the reasons why Drug Dealer Simulator deserves accolades for its engrossing gameplay, realistic mechanics, and dynamic storytelling.

Engaging Gameplay:
One of the most outstanding aspects of Drug Dealer Simulator is its deeply engaging gameplay. From the very start, players are tasked with building their drug empire from scratch, making every decision count. Whether it's scouting for the perfect location, managing resources, or negotiating with suppliers, each action has a tangible impact on the game's progression. The mechanics are skillfully designed to keep players invested in their virtual drug-dealing venture, providing a constant sense of achievement and satisfaction as they climb the ranks of the criminal underworld.

Realistic Simulation:
The game's developers have done an excellent job of creating a realistic drug-dealing simulation. Every aspect, from the buying and selling of drugs to evading the law enforcement, is intricately detailed and well-thought-out. The supply and demand mechanics are dynamic and responsive, making players feel like true entrepreneurs as they adapt their strategies based on market trends. The inclusion of law enforcement elements adds an extra layer of excitement and challenge, making each drug deal feel like a thrilling cat-and-mouse game.

Immersive World and Graphics:
Drug Dealer Simulator boasts an immersive open-world environment that feels alive and teeming with activity. The streets pulse with an authentic urban atmosphere, and NPCs (non-playable characters) add depth to the surroundings, making it feel like a bustling city with its own ecosystem of crime. The graphics are visually appealing and do justice to the dark and gritty theme of the game. The attention to detail in both the environments and character designs further enhances the overall gaming experience, drawing players deeper into the virtual criminal underworld.

Compelling Narrative:
Beyond its exceptional gameplay and mechanics, Drug Dealer Simulator weaves a compelling narrative that adds an emotional dimension to the game. Players will encounter various characters and make alliances, creating a sense of attachment to the evolving story. The decisions players make throughout the game significantly impact the storyline, providing an element of unpredictability and replay value. This approach ensures that each playthrough is unique, keeping players engrossed and eager to discover different outcomes.

Conclusion:
Drug Dealer Simulator on Steam is a masterful creation that successfully combines thrilling gameplay, realistic simulation, and an immersive world, all enveloped within a compelling narrative. Its strategic elements and dynamic mechanics make it a standout title in the simulation genre, while its gripping storytelling keeps players on the edge of their seats throughout their criminal journey. If you're seeking an adrenaline-pumping adventure that challenges your strategic prowess and storytelling abilities, Drug Dealer Simulator is undoubtedly a game worth exploring.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Edit:
I liked the game at first. A funny disclaimer on the loading screen, groovy music in the main menu, package management mechanics, a narrator's voice and even a flashlight on the phone. 

But the punishment system in this game spoiled my impression at all. Replaying all the long lost progress after I was caught by the cops (and lost all weed in the bag including 300$) who chase you like olympic runners because you didn't hear their female dispatcher on their radio and failed to see them in total darkness (and the game is really dark at nights) coming out unexpectedly from a corner was discouraging enough already. But i just completely gave up after I lost my bag completely thanks to the bug.
This game is probably good for others, but unfortunately it seemed too much grinding and punishing to me.

Stoked for DDS2!

Do you like baking? I do... I fucking love baking!
And now with DDS, you too can bake. Well, you can manufacture your own flavours of drugs, so its not the same but pretty close. 

What about gardening? That's pretty cool right?
Got some good news for you too, you can "Garden" in DDS. Albeit it's only weed. But you grow that shit en masse, flick it back to your garage drug lab, and never worry about buying it again. Shit grows out of the fucking ground.
Best part, flick it off for a tenner and BOOM! A sneaky (And ever so cheeky) PROFIT!

Do you like gardening AND baking? Mate, hold onto your chubby and get this.
Take that freshly cut grass you just spent weeks growing, crack it down into a crystalised product, whack that shit into the chopbox and you have powder.
Now you may be sitting there thinking;

"Sleepy, why would I ever want to take marijuana and turn it into a powder?"

Well, I am happy you asked my dear chumbah. Because you're gonna split it 50/50 with any other powder and you make more money for less. It's called "Diversification". Why does it work? Don't ask me how it works, I never give a fuck, it just does. Trust me. And it's awesome!

You got baking, gardening, public relations, business acumen, advertising, real estate acquisition, stealth, economics, chemistry and so much more! What the fuck more do you want from a simulator!? Do you hate fun? Do you love being boring? Just buy it.

Buy it right now, right fucking now! It doesn't matter if you're not autistic like me. Buy it or I will find where you live and tickle you with a feather until you do buy it. And you are going to enjoy it too. You're going to like it. You're going to love it even or, somebody is going to get fucking hurt!!

To close my review I will leave you with the synopsis along the lines of; 
"Selling drugs is great fun!"

This game is sick. It takes some time to learn how the recipes work (maybe unless you're actually a drug dealer), but after some determined googling I'm starting to get it down. 

It feels very free in that you can go at your own pace. I didn't open sector C until level 40 and I didn't even unlock most of sector B until after that. My point is, its tough to fall behind. You can disable and enable different drugs so you don't get orders for them. Apparently meth is notoriously tricky.

Definitely recommend, this game is addicting-- no pun intended. Can't wait for the second one. Apparently it will be coop. I hope it includes combat and/or the risk of being robbed. Add some more realism and it will go in the right direction.

I wanted to like this game, but as a PC gaming novice, the early game/tutorial isn't very effective and the UI/player experience aren't very intuitive. It took me 4 trips back and forth between my apartment and customers and a lot of trial and error to figure out how to split the first 6g of weed. Now I'm stuck at the workstation and can't figure out how to select "Package Product" from my small jar menu - I can't click it, none of the keys work to cycle through the menu options, and I've run out of ideas, so now my product is inaccessible and I can't make any more progress. I couldn't even save the game at that point to try again later, so I just gave up.

To put it bluntly (ha), I felt like this game is very good at telling you what to do, but not at explaining or walking you through how to do it.

I definitely would not recommend this game. If they add cars and at least one gun and forgot about the curfew then I might consider buying DDS2 but if they don't then it definitely would not be buying the next game.

Here is what I have to say with almost 100 hours played. DDS is enjoyable and a nice change of pace from the type of games the majority of people play, but it is broken by the amount of game breaking bugs and issues the game has had since release. When one bug gets fixed 10 more show up, the bugs either break immersion or make the game completely unplayable. I bought this game when it was $20 and it wasn't worth it because of the amount of bugs.

One of the main issues following this game is the constant crashes or the fact it uses 100% of your GPU power because it doesn't cap FPS and instead of adding an option in game to change it you have to go into the local files and edit the config manually which is ridiculous for an issue that the developers have been aware of for a long time.

There is no auto save feature so if your game crashes and you haven't saved in a while have fun, for some people the game doesn't even launch it just crashes immediately after downloading and you wasted your money for nothing.

This game honestly had so much potential and yet they keep working on graphical changes but they don't fix the hundreds of bugs the game has. The developers don't care about any of the issues and they just want your money don't buy this game it's just not really worth it until they fix all the issues (if they ever do)

Let me say one more thing to conclude this. This game is honestly a lot of fun but you have to go through hoops to mess with game files to even get the game working without crashes and issues if you're willing to do that then this game might be worth it to you if not then its not.
im the dopeman

Seriously addictive (no pun intended) and underrated game. Make all sorts of drug mixes and experiment with what works the best. All while managing your funds, both legal and illegal cash flow, avoiding police and expanding your territory. Well worth the price tag and beyond.

AFTER ENDGAME UPDATE:
I started up the game again and they made it even better. Compared to previous versions it has become a bit more grindey, but it is not a boring grind. Somewhere mid to late game you will be doing variety of tasks to maintain your nefarious enterprise. Anything from procuring and cutting drugs, to selling to clients, to supplying dealers, and eventually to investing into your laundering business front and some more endgame features ;)

New Sector C is the largest of the three and plenty of opportunities there as well. Gotta warn you though, this game is a huge time sink. It will suck you in like those junkies sucked into your drugs that you sell.

the most disappointing thing is that the game lacks gang violence and shootouts and territory control. I hope the sequel gets it... i don't expect it to play like call of duty or battlefield, but equipping dealers, having muscle, dodging police and fighting to the last man has to be at least a part of being a drug dealer simulator.

They cut this feature from the game most certainly, and there are many incomplete features that clearly they could have added, but they decided to drop this, sell it cheap, focus on the new game.
I applaud them for being willing to start fresh and offer a cut rate on their game... its a smart move. it'll bring the game to many people (and it already has) and like the drugs you peddle, you'll crave more, more more.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

[h1]An Immersive and Intense Criminal Underworld[/h1]

[h2]Visuals[/h2]
Drug Dealer Simulator offers a visually immersive experience that brings the dark and gritty criminal underworld to life. From the dilapidated streets to the dimly lit drug dens, the game's graphics capture the harsh realities of the drug trade. The attention to detail in the environments and character designs creates a realistic and atmospheric backdrop that draws players into the dangerous world they are about to navigate.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Prepare yourself for a gripping and intense gameplay experience as you step into the shoes of a drug dealer. From manufacturing and dealing drugs to managing your resources and evading law enforcement, every decision and action you take has consequences. The game offers a variety of activities, including crafting and upgrading equipment, negotiating with suppliers, and establishing a network of contacts. The immersive gameplay mechanics provide a sense of realism and challenge as you strive to rise to the top of the criminal hierarchy.

[h2]Storyline[/h2]
The narrative of Drug Dealer Simulator delves deep into the dark and morally ambiguous world of drug trafficking. As you progress through the game, you'll encounter complex characters, navigate dangerous alliances, and face unexpected twists and turns. The captivating storyline keeps players engaged, eager to uncover the secrets and unravel the mysteries of the criminal underworld.

[h2]Sound Design[/h2]
The sound design in Drug Dealer Simulator enhances the immersive experience, heightening the tension and atmosphere of the game. The haunting background music, coupled with the ambient sounds of bustling streets and police sirens, creates a sense of unease and urgency. The voice acting brings the characters to life, conveying the intensity and desperation of their circumstances.

[h2]Replayability[/h2]
Drug Dealer Simulator offers substantial replay value, thanks to its open-ended gameplay and branching paths. Each playthrough can result in different outcomes, depending on your choices and strategies. Whether you want to focus on expanding your drug empire, engaging in more illicit activities, or taking a riskier approach, the game allows for multiple playstyles and encourages experimentation.

[h2]Longevity[/h2]
With its deep gameplay mechanics, intricate storyline, and the vast world to explore, Drug Dealer Simulator offers hours of engaging content. From starting as a small-time dealer to becoming a powerful kingpin, the game provides a sense of progression and a desire to conquer the criminal underworld. The developers' commitment to regular updates and additional content ensures that players have a long-lasting and evolving experience.

In summary, Drug Dealer Simulator offers an immersive and intense journey into the criminal underworld. Its realistic visuals, gripping gameplay, intriguing storyline, immersive sound design, and replayability make it a game that will captivate fans of the genre. Strap in for a thrilling and morally complex adventure as you navigate the dangerous world of drug dealing in this gripping and immersive simulation.
