I love this game and I probably couldn't make a better one even if I had five of me, however, it's a little shit. Start is fun and well paced but then it goes downhill and fast. The pace gets far slower, the idea of talking to people basically vanishes. Sure you can use text options but you rarely hear any voice lines for the rest of the game. I was honestly startled by my own characters voice because it had been so long since I heard it and I didn't know who it was. They made it so people in VERY large areas will only buy certain drugs making other drugs inconvenient to sell since you can't sell them quickly without spending thousands of dollars for another house and equipment. Example, I was selling mainly amp until I unlocked cocaine which any sensible person would switch to for its cash gain but no, nobody will buy it except for people from up north which is inconvenient as fuck because 90% of my clients are not from the area I just unlocked some levels ago which slows down the pace even farther. How reputation works is just so strange, you spraypaint on some walls for five minutes then everyone in the whole district loves you. One last thing, Bugs..fix them. Again I love this game but still the flaws are apparent and easy to find.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

[h1] The Typical PlayWay Game. [/h1]

So, you're thinking about buying DDS, because you're somewhat interested in a good management game and have no shame for looking like a 15 year old to all your friends.

So, here's a short answer and a long answer for you:

[u] Short Answer [/u]

Don't. You'll be disappointed. Most of the people that play it, and still do, are.

[u] Long Answer [/u]

This game is the typical PlayWay game. What do I mean by this? Let me explain.

PlayWay's business model consists of, and has always consisted of "Quantity over Quality." You know those developers that spend years on top of years tweaking, playtesting and making their games better? Yeah, that's not PlayWay.

The way they went about DDS is the same way they go about any and all of their games:

- Trailer with empty promises, which are never delivered upon no matter how long you wait.

- Gets announced with 15 other Simulator games ranging from "sounds fun" to "this is ridiculous." 

- Abandoned after half a year of further development.

- Half-baked updates, when they do come out, that add nothing to the game whatsoever and probably got cut before release, "fixed" and re-implemented.

Like any of their games, this ends up in a loop of: "Develop for one year, drop a demo, get complaints, fix some of them, ignore others, and out the door we go."

Just look at the amount of announced games, there's so, so many of them. All developed by one company, and no matter how many sub-companies they create themselves to divert the attention from the ridiculous crunch their developers suffer, it's still the same company.

They saturate the market with half-baked garbage and expect your money, just wait until they find out about the Early Access System.


Now to the actual game, Thief Simulator, but with Drugs.

- Recipe Mixing has a right and wrong way, no inbetween. There's variations in the marginal grams that some people swear on, but it's all the same. Listed conveniently on their Discord.

- Stealth System is the same as in Thief Simulator, the Cops see you through walls and arbitrarily decide if they want to arrest you through a wall or not.

- Working at daytime is the same as working at nighttime, just without the scary music and you fill an arbitrary meter that ends up in a raid, which is the same as a game over, essentially, because the DEA takes all your stuff.

- They have an actual channel on their Discord for translations for the game by users, because they can't be bothered to do it themselves or hire someone that can speak English. Get used to gems such as: "Trash Cupboad", "US dolas" and my favorite "Text Block" which pops up everywhere they don't want to translate or haven't done so. This is me not including stuff such as "noe" instead of "now" and missing letters everywhere. There's people pretending that having NPCs spell every second word wrong gives the game a "realistic feel." Yes, this is how bad it's gotten.

- They promised guns, never delivered them. 

- They promised the player to be able to use drugs, didn't deliver.

That's just 2 examples, the list is long. Just look for the old game trailer on YT.

tl;dr: DDS is fun for 10 hours, then gets boring, repetitive and probably breaks your savegame and softlocks some missions. Don't buy it.

A complex and multifaceted drug economy to dominate, built on a hybrid stealth / fetch-quest simulator.  [list][*]The equipment interfaces needs some quality of life / consistency fixes.  [*]Currently lacks a second game mode stripping out the progress-gating story missions.[/list]   

Going all mad-science with drug mixtures is where the game truly shines.  
Making [spoiler]cough cough[/spoiler] [i]happy[/i] customers and perhaps [i]not[/i] killing them may involve a bit of [b]Math[/b]. [spoiler]Not Even Once(tm)[/spoiler]

I found making drug mixtures for my player character to take to be particularly entertaining.  My favorite mix was mostly stimulants for [i]performance[/i] with hallucinogens for cool [i]whoosh-and-tinnitus[/i] effects to make evading the law more dramatic.  I never quite got a night vision mix I was happy with, but trying was memorable.  

Drugs which alter the passage of game time, visual effects, and character movement speed can be frustrating when too intense.  
Sometimes one drugs' effects would functionally cancel out another drug's inconvenient effects.  Thus, the drug mixes I was after would manage (balance) side effects. 
So I could take 'em and still run around doin' stuff.  Okay I'm gonna go back to being factual now.  Tip your waitperson.

[h1]Positive[/h1][list][*][b]Fun[/b] interface changes when the player character takes [b]drugs[/b].  [*]Robust custom [b]drug mixing[/b] system.  [*][b]Escalating police presence[/b] and DEA raids.  [*]Drug [b]concealment[/b] and [b]smuggling[/b] mechanics.  [*][b]RPG features[/b] such as leveling up for skill points.  
[*]Game is still being actively expanded.[*]Game is often on sale at a reduced price.[/list]

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[list][*]Issues with already-released content are never addressed.[*]Inconsistent [b]laboratory equipment[/b] interfaces.[/list]

[b]Mouse Wheel Fatigue[/b]
[list][*]All lab equipment requires use of a right-click (context) menu to operate.  [*]This menu requires the use of  the [b]scroll wheel[b] to walk a cursor down the list of options.  [*]The most frequently chosen options, Add Substance and Make Package, are bizarrely the [b]second[/b] and [b]second-to-last[/b] options.  This one-off placement causes frequent targeting errors and corrective mouse-wheel motions.  The additional wear-and-tear on both finger and mouse are significant. fatigue.[/list]

[b]Dialogue Menu Nightmare[/b]
[list][*]Many dialogues pop up deeply deselected, [b]requiring[/b] the mouse be used to click the dialogue.[/list]
[i]Where the heck is it that mouse cursor??[/i]
[list][*]These dialogues' mouse-cursor position moves while one moves the mouse to aim and select things in the [b]main movement interface[/b].  
[*]This causes the mouse cursor to appear in a [b]random position[/b] Every. Single. Time.  

[*]Which necessitates wiggling the mouse cursor to find it.  Every. Single. Time.
[*]The newly [i]located[/i] mouse-cursor must be moved from that random position to [i]exactly where it was left seconds earlier[/i] to click the exact same button.
[*]An increasingly peevish percussive clatter is heard from the mouse as it is ‚Äòreset‚Äô to a position which allows comfortable use of the FPS interface.  [/list]

A totally addicting game, pun intended. This game is simple in the concept yet surprisingly complex once to get into it. 
You deal drugs working your way up to getting your own dealers that you supply. Pretty simple right, wrong. To do this you gotta order from the cartel and still manage to make some extra cash after you sell to your clients. This is were cutting and mixing your Drugs come in. This can get complex, but is in my opinion is where the game shines. 
Cops are total A**e* in this game, it is great. Running from the cops is seriously intense the first time, and every time after still makes your heart pump a little.

The game does have some bugs that can be an issue at times and some polishing couldn't hurt. Updates to the game are a bit of an issue as they are slow to roll out and bugs tend to not get fixed. Despite this the game has a bit of a cult following and it is easy to see why. 
I would recommend this game to anyone looking for an unusual simulation game.

This game promised to be something that it is not... It is full of bugs, with very poorly implemented and crappy mechanics, which is far from being like in the trailer. The developers only add minor updates from time to time, adding more bugs to the game. And they use it as a claim to advertise other games. Steam does nothing to prevent this type of activity, apparently, being impossible to report this behavior.

And this is the only way I have to report this fact to the community.

Don't buy it! After paying for it, I think it's better to play it in other ways...

This game is unfinished, buggy and kind of a let down.  It is still fun as a casual, 1 player game to play between other activities, just not what it was originally advertised as. I bought this game a year or more ago and realized that it was far from finished, and did not have many of the features originally advertised in the trailer. I started playing again a week or so ago, only to find out that they seemingly only added one major feature (growing MJ) and did not fix many bugs. For example: One bug (the one where you randomly can't interact with your dealers and they are just permanently waiting for you to collect cash) has existed for over two years based on steam forums and still has not been fixed. Now the company that made DDS is marketing a new simulator (Prison King) with a trailer that has similar high promises as DDS's original trailer.  I recommend you buy neither until DDS is fixed and lives up to its company's original promises.

This game is really fun and has a lot of potential. I absolutely hate the packaging mechanics.. Its tedious and not fun at all. If a customer wants a 57 gram bag of weed then you have to make a 50g bag, a 5g bag and a 2 g bag...... over and over its tedious and unrealistic. You'll spend a lot of time packaging in stupid ways instead of enjoying the fast pace stealth and rewarding growth of your drug empire. It gets pretty overwhelming quickly trying to package all those drugs bag by bag. IRL if you  buy drugs they dont give you 5 bags. This shitty mechanic alone really breaks the game for me. It gives no incentive to want more customers because you simply cant pack shit fast enough. PLZ fix this because this game could be amazing

********* Updated review****
previously i would have said buy this. BUT, i have given the game about 70hrs or so now. Its so stale. I had even taken a break for a week or two to see if it'd have the spark again. But, as soon as i loaded in and remembered where i was at, i checked the laptop for orders etc and everyone who could need/want something had requested a delivery. By the time you have sorted the orders and delivered, the dealers are asking to meet to give cash or people want more. i knew that it would be tedious so i didn't even continue. There so much more that could be added to this for incentive but it just isn't there. After i had discovered the phych drugs "gang" and the fat dude in the club i thought the game was going to change so you wouldn't have to do the running so much, that wasn't the case. Just more drugs at a shittier price than you get from your punters. So with that in mind, This is all you will do on this game, 

-check laptop
-confirm order
-weigh out product
-pick locks (they lock again when the day is over so you need a constant supply of bobby pins)
-take to dealer/client
-run from police
-search for your backpack you threw in a chase
-collect money
-buy "nice" furniture for your shitty house in the ghetto
-take money to eddie to pay mafia
-order more drugs
-pick up more drugs
-check the available property and not buy anything
-rinse and repeat

you can unlock more parts of town and apartments, however, once you have a strong dealer and client base on one side of town, unlocking more places makes everything even harder to manage when it comes to supply and demand. messing around with the checkpoints to get to other parts of town to deliver/collect and navigating in the sewers gets boring really fast. side quests are minimal and dry. The police aren't really a problem as you can save before you leave your hideout. Thus being caught means a reload and go again. Silly things make this game annoying once you've made some cash. Even once you are able to purchase your own growing seeds its yet another thing to try and squeeze into the constant annoyance of your phone/laptop going off for orders and keeping up supply and demand, even with your own dealers.  
the game works ok though, no crashes or anything like that. From what i have read is that the dev's are no longer really interested in this game and updates have dried up. Shame really as it does have so much potential. my original review is below, i did previously give this game a thumbs up. 

=====================================================================================

Had a couple of glitches but nothing serious. I am looking forward to what the developers are going to add in the future.

An extremely fun and decently accurate experience. The game has a bunch of content so you'll definitely be busy for hours and the grind in game is super satisfying to complete. Would definitely recommend.

A little tough to get started (I restarted like 3 times in the beginning) until you get the hang of what to do, but it is feeding the simulator itch. Definitely check out the wiki for correct mixes and recipes to follow.

Edit: FINALLY got a good game going. Almost unlocked all the areas, but ran into the bug where I cannot interact with one of my dealers. Therefore missing some income. It's not game breaking BUT it's super annoying when you constantly have another icon on your map for someone that you cannot interact with, constantly throwing you off of where you need to go. I still recommend the game, it's given me hours of entertainment. This bug has been around since the release, so I don't know if it will be fixed but I HOPE it does. Doing some research, it seems this bug occurs when you are interacting with the dealer and get stopped by the police, which is exactly what happened to me. BE CAREFUL!

I will probably start another game since I didn't realize how early I could have unlocked psychedelics, but I really hope this doesn't happen again.

Very fun. I have played through two campaigns.

I just wish there were less of me having to run around too much in late game. I think an improvement would be managing drops and dealers instead of delivering everywhere all the time in late game. Also, watering indoor weed plants is required too often: it's tedious, and even difficult -- when they're near full growth.

Basically, after you get off the ground, there needs to be a way to delegate tasks, because in late game, I find that I am spread too thin to actually expand. One person can't do everything, and I'd like to relax and watch money come in from a system I've set up instead of constantly working more.

Also, after all the tasks are completed, there's no point in being rich. What do I need to buy? Nothing. The most appealing option at that point is starting over.

I am hoping for a good update to really make this an empire rather than just a one-person business where I spend every moment racing to satisfy clients and keep plants alive as more and more is demanded of me.

Those are my gripes, but I really enjoyed this game. It is a gem, even if it needs some reform, so to speak.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. The game is great, it's awesome and there aren't really any other games that do what this one does anywhere near as well as this one.  for the most part.

the problem: There isn't enough content to keep you going...   after about 10-15 hours of playing, you'll be at a point where you have everything unlocked (for the most part), and will be making so much cash you can't do anything with it.  
because there is only so much stuff to spend your money on.  buy a new small shed in each of the zones, and/or a small apartment. (I think that there are like 15-20 purchasable "properties" which isn't much in the scope of the game, as what you can do with your properties is extremely limited, specifically. you can buy your small apartment or shed, and then buy some of the few furniture items for it.   which essentially are: Cheap bed, couch, chair, table, etc.  Decent bed, couch, chair, table, etc. or Expensive bed, couch chair table etc.          as well as a few things like cabinets for storage, or a "wardrobe" that lets you "change your clothes" (Doesn't actually change how you look as you can't see your playermodel.)  or buy some paintings/decorative plants.

other than that for actual functional stuff you can buy, is where the game shines, you can buy various drug mixing/making equipment, ranging from cheap and inefficient ways of doing things like using an electric coffee grinder, a hand mortar and pestle.  all the way up to using high end lab grade equipment, such as: lab grade centrifuges, lab grade precision mixers, Flasks to break down drugs for mixing, to pill pressing machines to make your own pills. and so on.  

This aspect of the game is amazing and is done so well, in my opinion no other game does it better.   

the dealing itself is fairly fun, while avoiding police patrols, and trying to keep your "suspicion" or "heat" level down, all while trying to deliver the "goods" as fast as you can in order to keep your dealer rating as high as can be. (which in turn lets you charge higher prices for your "goods")

the game loop is repetitive, but very fun in itself.   the problem is, the game lacks any real "content" after you get to the point when you're selling to gangs in huge quantity. example,   some of the more expensive properties to buy are only like $4000  and you can make upwards of 20-30K when selling to gangs in bulk...  which means off of a few sales to gangs you can easily make enough cash to essentially be able to buy everything.   and then there isn't much reason to continue selling. 

This issue essentially is you just get into the "good" part of the game right around the time you unlock gangs,  (the "good" part of the game is when you get access to all of the "merchandise" to sell.  as all of the merchandise in the game is locked behind a level restriction.      so around the same time you finally unlock all the end game stuff, (H, Coke, Fentanyl,) and can start making these crazy mixes with the Fentanyl,  which is when the game really shines as you have to go through numerous steps in your lab to make a super drug.       you unlock the gangs, and that makes it so making your own super drugs is almost irrelevant.  because why should I waste my time making a super drug to sell and make a few thousand dollars over hours of work. when I can just bulk buy coke, or meth, and do a cheap cut, and sell it for 30K?)



So all in all, the game is amazing, it just doesn't have enough end game content, or reason to keep you playing.    

But the devs don't really care about the game, and barely put any work into updating it.


so far they push out a "MAJOR UPDATE" every year or so, and it adds a tiny bit of content. almost like they have one or 2 people working on DDS still, and the rest of the studio is working on other projects.     


but Movie Games S.A. and PlayWay S.A. are known to be scummy publishers who release unfinished products, hype them up, and get people to buy them, then run away with the cash. 

Unfortunately Byterunners ( the games devs) appear to have none, or almost no, active media presence... which means no way to tell how big of a company they are, or if they are a legitimate company. or if they're owned by MovieGames or Playway.

I just wish they could put a little bit more focus on this game, or try to force the publiser(s) they partnered with to help put some elbow grease into making this game better.

as if they did, I believe this game could be incredibly huge and popular.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead- murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time - something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange - uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" - on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

It will definitely keep you on your toes. I'm just hoping it will get continued support and updates as promised.

honestly I was so excited for getting this game but I cant even play it as I haven't even gotten past the main menu. When I click start new game it would take me to the loading screen and just keep me there forever.

So after re-visting the game after a year or so, I was pleasantly surprised. A year ago, the game just had zero purpouse, the only fun stuff was checking wether your clients had overdosed if you alterd the drug mix. The psychadelics gang was fun for a bit, but not my type of thing. But after the new updates (and I'm talking gameplay updates, not some hyped graphics/performance updates) I got pulled right into grinding this game again. The devs added a new sector, new shops, new passage ways (sewers + a hiden passage way that connects sector C and A), the new money laundering system is great and personally it is the thing that keeps me grinding the game since I've unlocked all drugs and hideouts. Also, new decorations like safes and posters are added (not much, but atleast you can splash some cash laying around). 
The other bit I need to comment since I've played the game on/off since it's release is the following: People who played this game for 20+ hours feel the need to criticise the devs because "It doesn't look like it did in the trailer" and "We were promised much more". I've got two repsonses for that sort of comments that unfortenately tank DDS's ratings. First off, the game costs 15‚Ç¨, so even if you don't like it, you can comfort yourself knowing that you didn't spend 50‚Ç¨+ like some people did with Cyber Punk and similar overhyped, underperforming games. 
Second, DDS gets updates that do take time, but the gameplay updates so far are pretty sweet (which motivates the player to grind the deals and collect cash). It will take time until the game "looks like it did in the trailer", but again; for 15‚Ç¨ I'd say it's a damn good deal. We've gotten 1/3 map expansion that also brought new clients and dealer, new shops, new passage ways, new hideouts, new characters, new additives, the new money laundering system and so on without paying any extra!
All in all, I can't reccomend this game to people who are clinged to the original trailer (if you realy want to know what the game is like before buying; watch some youtube gameplays because there's a lot of them now), however the game is perfect for grinding and becoming emerged in the world that the game takes place in.

Well, if you're reading this and you don't have a lot of time to waste, here's the short version: go back to the store page, pick any other game and thank me later.

You might be behind your computer screen, like I once was, picturing yourself having a hell of a good time slinging dope, mixing dope and making "beaucoup bucks" in the process. You might argue that this game actually allows you to do it and, since I'm honest, I couldn't disagree with you. If you put enough time and energy in your playthrough, you might just achieve that. However, this comes at a cost: absolute frustration. Let me explain.

The architecture absolutely sucks. Last gen processors and this game are like a lactose intolerant person and a 10 gallon milk pail. Even if you get it to work, the optimization (if there's any to begin with) is so poor that you might as well run 3 AAA games on ultra, simulteanously. Stuttering and screen freezes will be your best pals during your gaming session.

The content itself is fun at first but quickly becomes repetitive. As someone whom enjoys the process, the first few hours of gameplay (leaving aside bugs and other nuisances) are great. You sling your stuff and try not to get tazed by the cops. You finally get out of mom's basement (aka the cartel's appartment) and get yourself a nice empty property that you fill with "tools" and furniture. Wonderful. However, as you make more and more money, two queen-sized issues appear: 1. What shall I buy next? 2. Welcome to monotonousness.

Many appartments are for sale but how many do you really need? Three sectors, three condos, basta. Now that you filled and decorated them, what will you spend your money on? A full blown casino chain to launder your money! Oh yeah, you are a "partner" in a multi-million casino chain but you still have to sell 2g of "whatever you're selling" to some guy whose name would make a polish scholar stutter and you still live in a ghetto that makes Ohio look like the Maldives. Anyways, what shall I buy next? A lab? A manager? Well, I got some bad news for you: nothing. You basically enter a vicious circle of: get money, put it in a dresser, order more, repeat. You get stuck. Let me give you a warm welcome into the marriage-breaking realm of monotonousness.

There is no endgame. You begin by working for cartel. Fast forward a bunch of sales, you reach level 20 and, depending on your play style, you will either work for: Pablo Escobar if diabetes wasn't a thing or Kiryu Kazuma with a serious substance abuse problem. Money used to be good when completing these transactions but now you basically deliever next to nothing and, of course, get paid less that a student working a summer job at McDonald's. Nothing more. You've reached the end of the story line.

"But dude, they release updates and it will develop further! You gotta wait, dude. Be patient, dude.". Yeah, and I'm the Queen of England. Each update has been heavily criticized as it tends to: reduce playability, ignore previous bugs and add new bugs. Also, don't expect to get news from the devs. If you see news on Steam, it'll probably read something like: "Check out this new bundle." or "We are working hard on the next update, Anyways, check out this new bundle.". No updates, no fixes, not hotfixes, nada. This is the sad state of this game.

So there you go, my honnest opinion about this game. A game with an amazing potential that could've been something out of this world. Do whatever you want with this information but, if I may give you a piece of advice, spend your money elsewhere.

If you reached this last paragraph, I'd like to thank you for your time. I hope that you got some entertainment out of this review. My apologies for any typos. Have a good day and stay hydrated :)

Amazing simulator and I feel ready to be a drug dealer.

Game has lots of room for improvement, and I note that it is being upgraded regularly - new zones, ability to grow your own drug, money laundering - and I can see lots of potential ways to expand on this simulator.
Another critique is a lack of self-care stats - you don't have to eat, sleep, defecate, socialise, have fun, have sex, etc. - would be nice to actually have to care for yourself and not just your clientele.

EDIT: After 2 years they STILL don't care about this game. All they do is shill the other garbage games that PLAYWAY SA is funding. I have lost all hope for this game. All they do is LIE. LIE and LIE MORE. Don't Bother. Buy Rouge Legacy 2. A game thats actually worth it. 
TL:DR. Games an unfinished mess of a cash grab that should have been Early Access. The devs Byterunners Game Studio along with the publisher/s Movie Games S.A., PlayWay S.A. should be avoided entirely. We were promised the world and got nothing.
  
As much as I would love to recommend this game, No way in high Heaven or hell can I do so.
The game is absolutely bursting at the seems with potential, But sadly none of this will be realized or ever come to fruition.
This game for all intents and purposes should have been released in early access. 
Its runs poorly. Terrible optimization, No matter what pc I use I can't get it to run with any consistent amount of frames. Which is a shock considering the game isn't the prettiest thing to look at.
The bugs and glitches that are present are staggering! I've lost multiple save files for random reasons.
Now the major deal breaker, There is NO middle/end game content. No story. No meaningful progression what so ever. Nothing to spend your money on. (well a part from buying more drugs and things to cut and store drugs) It just turns into a running simulator after the first few hours. *Go to computer->Accept client->->Run.->Run some more->Keep running->Run even more->Rinse and repeat.*    
We were told that the devs had at least six months of funding and huge plans! Well its been five months and there have been less than a handful of updates. The only major one that lets the player "Grow" pot. (Which looks like they ripped it from a ps1 game the asset looks so bad).
The dev's have what seems to be gone into hiding. Releasing little to no information. 
When asked when we can see any sort of meaningful update we are met with "Soon" or "Around the corner" no matter how many weeks and months go by. Because of this a toxic community has formed around this game. A passionate but toxic community that like me see so much missed potential in this cash grab of a game. 
Do yourself a favor and don't buy this. Its as wide as the ocean but deep as a puddle. 
Don't support these dev's that don't care about releasing a game that is clearly in no way finished. That's not even mentioning the false advertising when this game came out.  
Don't support the publishers that are releasing a whole wave of garbage cash grab simulators. (Eg; Barn finders, Prison Simulator, Bum simulator. Just to name a few)
They brag about having 84 dev teams. All working on cash grab crap.

Ok so i'll start off saying the game is fun in it's own way , i still feel like i'll be on a DEA / FBI watchlist for playing it and watching the crazy amount of YouTube videos to learn how to play it. LMAO 
But any-who , game works great , i've not ever had a single game crash yet. 

Good : 
- Fun game to pass the time. 
- I know know how to make drugs LOL 
- Graphics are solid 60+ FPS
- Music is ok , matches the game. 
- Walking/Running simulator 
- Stealth works alright. 


BAD : 
- Game has the feeling of a warzone. 
- Almost no one on the map. Train goes by a few times ever , almost never see people just wandering. 
- Cops are glitchy sometimes (Just random spawning)
- No Game guide or tutorial(s)
- Very very redundant.  nothing changes once you get high level. just grind and grind. 
- Game needs MORE content. (Bigger map , AI competition , More life to the map.)

UGLY : 
- There really is an issue with Police Searching you , Guy will check you , and then check you again a few feet down the road. 
- Game needs some sort of transportation. (Rollerblades , Skate board , a kick-Scooter) Something ! 


Game Needs/Ideas : 
- Game NEEDS a in-depth tutorial on how to mix items and why. 
- Game NEEDS a way to save a recipe you liked for kinda quick-craft. (Maybe have a notebook in-game and you can choose a recipe you liked - In doing that would highlight a text on screen of the recipe so you don't have to remember it.)  
- Would be nice to hire a trusted someone to work in your lab (Mixing stuff , packaging) 
- Game needs more 'Feel' to it. just feels like i'm trapped in a city that is nearly dead. 
- Game needs a way to Un-rent a property. 
- Would be nice to BUY a property . (I'm a person that likes to run out of one building)
- I wish there was a Building editor (Make it bigger , move walls , Cover windows) 

Closing : 
I bought this game on a sale so i got it cheap , and for what i payed , i feel i got my moneys worth 5-fold. 
I like it , it passed time and i learned some s**t along the way. 
Why should you buy it ?? well it is actually a fun game dispite how hard it is to learn about drugs and what-not. it's a mun Management/Sneaking around game. 

IS IT WORTH A BUY ?   YES

Update: This game still has potential but I feel like what the developpers are doing goes against what you have to do in the game to progress. I played this game for almost 150h now and managing the first sector and only the first gets really insane, you are able to make a ton of cash, get your customers addicted and level up your dealers. The level up system is sick and was really needed. But then you move on to other sector and they are just not worth it... You can make 11k in sector A per night or do 300$ in Sector B... And when you get to Sector C it's just too tricky to be worth it, Sector C is really nice and well made, I would be really happy if it would be worth the trouble when you get to it buy setting up a lab to do a 3g run is really bad. What I think would make the game better is either choosing where you want to start, addind difficulty with each sector or maybe having a kind of ''automatic managing'' as in you get a dealer high level enough so he can manage a part of a sector or a whole sector then you can focus on keeping him stocked, taking your money from the stash and then building up your next sectors. That would make the game so much worth and more enjoyable. I know you are trying to make a better game for us but right now I feel like we can't enjoy the way we deserve to.

This game has something compelling about it, I just love the mechanics and features; the map is detailed and graphics are beautiful; it has a lot of potential to be even better.
It has quite a lot of bugs aswell which are getting fixed slowly but surely, and hoping that the Dev team keeps working on it and especially add mod support :)

Just friendly disclaimer about this game: If you're looking to try this game out; I recommend downloading the free demo "Free Sample" so you get a feel for it and if your PC is good enough to run it smoothly or atleast pump out 30 FPS. Also, this game sadly has a very short story; which makes the game really repetitive at the end (about 10-20 hours depending on how fast you progress; and from player to another it might get boring if you don't mix your playstyle up a bit) where you just have to order cocaine, cut it, deliver, repeat. The game needs more depth to the story, more quality of life improvements (higher order limit for example, & making bins functional so we can dump unneeded items like the suit cases you get from the gangs) and mod support again ;)

All in all, I recommend the game.

I bought this game when it first released. Although the team has been releasing updates for the game, i think there are areas for improvement. I'm just going to name a few.
-When making drugs you can't see anything. For example, when mixing there is nothing in the pot. When putting liquid in a flask there is nothing in there as well. It's a hit to the immersion.
-No more reskins of drugs. Every single drug other than weed and ecstasy virtually has the same appearance. Very minor but it takes away from immersiveness.
-More things to buy. I appreciate having many avenues to move and make drugs, but it's all for nothing to get rich just to buy MORE drugs. No recreation or activities to spend this money on.
-The new money laundering system is also cool but it would be nice to SEE the business. Or be able to run a shop of some sort arouind town. Another avenue of minimal passive income that i can see.

All in All even though the orginal trailer was a far cry from the current game, i love this game, i truly do. I am only being critical cause i want the developers to learn and grow from this. Listen to the people and keep up to good work!

It was a fun game to play at first, but the magic of the game kind of wears off after a day or two. It's very repetitive and after reaching rank 15 there becomes not much to really do other than rinse and repeat. There's no items or things to buy to have fun when not selling narcotics in the game. The ai is also very broken.  They will stop you straight after their first time searching you and sometimes follow you around the district after searching you (which can only be fixed by closing the games launcher). There's also a bug in game were if the narcotic is slightly changed the ai will decline to take it if you have a pure version of the narcotic alongside it. 

I highly wouldn't recommend this game, but if you decide to pick it up, get it when it's on sale.

God, I want to like and recommend this game so much, but there are so many random fucked up bugs where, for example, your stash disappears, or orders come in that you didn't even confirm, or cops will sometimes search you, then immediately search you again lol. Or just annoying mechanics/controls, like the workbench feels janky to work with. Or no minimap so you're constantly going back and forth between map and gameplay to figure out where you are. The guide/compass doesn't have orthogonal directions indicating NWSE. Or the janky save where some of your shit disappears once you reload? Or the fact that you have to buy multiple LAPTOPS for each of your hideouts, instead of being able to carry it with you? Or the fact your phone seems to literally only be useful as a flashlight...you can't read messages, yet there is a prompt to do so, it's like they were gonna implement this feature, then said fuck it and forgot about it lol.

This game is generic guys. I mean yeah. You sell drugs. Whoopty do. My main complaint is that there is no real reason to play. There is no goal or focus. No story line. Its a basic cookie cutter formula for any small business game. Small tutorial, acquire product, sell product, get better product, sell all products. Only thing is, in other games there are incentives clearly laid out for the user to work towards. This game gets INCREDIBLY repetitive FAST. As long as you have basic inventory management skills, this game gets dull. You quickly start to feel like an errand boy. At NO point in this game do you ever feel like a king pin and have people selling drugs for you or helping you make money. There is no Coop mode at all. The developers are so far up on their high horse telling you how theyve done this HUGE update and overhaul and insist on trying the game on a new save(Which I did) and I honestly didnt notice not once change to anything. They added the ability to buy crypto..... cool........ Like you have furniture options to save TONS of money and spend it on but for what? So YOU can look at it? Uhh Cool? Your friends cant come and appreciate your drug house so whats the point? Not to mention that for a game SO simple it runs your machine HARD. Like under load playing Apex legends or other AAA title games I average around 75-78C this game had my GPU running at 90C so I cant imagine that is healthy for your machine. Its for these reasons that I can not recommend the game in its current state. The devs brag about performance fixes and Ive seen or experienced none of these alleged "fixes" I have owned this game for a very long time and NOTHING has changed. It even seems like nothing gets updated or added either. These developers are bragging about and over glorifying a half polished turd.

I updated this review and most of it no longer applies, see the update before you make a decision on this game. (It's worth what they're asking)

It's good, I do recommend it, there's no endgame though, you reach a point where you have so much money just from working with the gang there's nothing left to do. Why would I run from one side of the map to the other to sell 40g. When I can sell 2.5kg.

There's also a serious flaw with the mixing, if you want to mix large quantities, good luck, by the time you're mixing 1kg batches there's not enough mixing material available from the shop. The gang are asking for increasing quantities each day, I'm currently at 2.5kg. I can not get enough mixing material to make this much so I just sell them the pure stuff. Would be nice to be able to keep on mixing at this point.

Update on 04/04/22: 

It's better, the gang doesn't request ridiculous amounts anymore and the dealers that work for you request more than 40g now. You're now able to buy as much mixing materials as you like and not a set amount each day. You can travel through the sewers in a much more involved way to get to the other side of the map, the map has been expanded and new zones have been added.

so i bought this game on sale a few months back as a joke, only thinking i'd launch it up once to mess around a little and then refund it. i really didn't think much of it upon first glance; it just seemed like another one of those sh!tty unity dump games with bare-bones content and no replayability.

oh, oh i was so wrong.

while yes, this is certainly a sh!tty unity dump game, the amount of content there is to offer actually blows me away. in my first and current playthrough, im currently at level 30 sitting on 15 grand in cash underneath of my bed in the oldtown warehouse that i owe to the cartel, meanwhile i've lined the garages around me up with drug stashes and weed growing operations. i've easily got a few hundred grams of just about every drug sitting in jars across my apartment, garages, and warehouse, and i feel like i've barely even scratched the surface as i'm now helping a psychadelics gang hunt down a rat in sector B.

i really hope the devs don't abandon this game. there's so much to offer here and i have really no complaints at all. for a game you'd expect to be riddled with bugs and unplayable errors, i've come in to 0 problems over my current 11 hours of gameplay and nearly 2 weeks in game.

devs, PLEASE keep up the great work and continue pushing out more content for this game, i can't wait to see what the future holds for drug dealer simulator

Great game over all, lots to do and learn when starting off.

Ideas for the future:
- On Shady Comm, Order the Users/Dealers by the area they are in  (Ex. Sector A first, Sector B Second, Sector C Third)
- Or allow custom ordering of the Users/Dealers
- Make it possible to do Drop offs to your dealers in Trash Cans and Such
- Or make it so you can have 1 or more Top Distributor(s) per Sector that gives the orders to the Dealers, and collects the money from them (Send you the Request, Requiring 1 Day to give out, 1 Day to collect, 1 day Request you to collect the money they have, and Sends the next order the next day)
- Make it so one of the Casinos you own are in the town so you can gamble
- Make Hideouts that are more open (just one big room)
- When buying items that get deliver to your hideouts, allow players to select multiple hideouts (Ex. you buy 2 computers, you can select 2 hideouts that each gets one of them)
- Create a Club or something similar that you can buy in a Sector that allows you to do Multiple Big orders with cool down (Ex. 500g+ orders, 3-5 day cool down each)
- Remove the "Collect Money" Tasks pop ups when on the Work Tables, and Show more orders on the side
- Add a drug reference table somewhere for people that do not know the terms for all drugs
- Perhaps add an option to bribe the police
- CHANGE THE GATES SYSTEMS. Should not require you to unlock it every time you go to use it.
- The backpack update they did was terrible, change it back to a max weight, not slots.

Just a side thing, i have Shad coins, like physical coins that are in my cabinets that i don't know what to do with it, i don't remember how i got it, but i don't know what I am supposed to do with it.

Just some thoughts that would make the game better

Great example of world-building. A realistic depiction of an American police state in a city "a few years from now". Now that it is actually 2022, the year the game is set, I can say you got it right on for some places! (except for the whole Covid pandemic thing.).
I wish that the story was more fleshed out though, although I do enjoy just experiencing the fucked-up game world. I'm glad that you are still working on and updating the game. Here's hoping the real-life world not getting any more fucked up!

Dev's did a good job in the ways to buy, sell and manage a business it kept me interested, its simple to use the U.I and they didn't go over the top with it,great game for business savvy people if you don't mind the drugs which i think is a bit tacky. 
Although I wouldn't recommend it because the early access really begins to show between mid to late game, its very buggy and in places you don't want bugs,progression begins to stagnate and become horribly repetitive, and this is a "Drug Running Simulator" with a big emphasise on the "RUNNING", i cant get the time back i spent in this game but hopefully this post will save yours.

The bugs that killed the experience for me:
Some orders don't appear on the taskbar until you meet up with the client who ordered them making you do double the running for nothing.

La Ballena wont send orders through until i save and restart the game.

One of my dealers has become a street ornament and wont interact at all just stuck in the same place and withholding a lump some of money from me.

Sometimes during searches or before they start police will randomly aggro even whilst im standing still which turns into a loop of non stop tasers, where i wake up at the police station and the police are still aggro and taser me again. :/

Only a little repetitive, but there are always different things to do. So far I find it hard to put this game down. It's fun to build your own little empire. You go around the town delivering your product to various clients that you pick up, all while avoiding being caught by the police. I joke about how this is the game they warn parents about, lol. Highly recommend if you like simulators like this.

Very great game, recommend it overall. Though this game has some flaws which I feel the need to point out to everyone before buying this game. Heres the issues you may encounter.

Bugs, it happens often but its something that can be avoided. Mostly happens if you are unlucky and it rarely happens. Examples? When it said "Cop Search", and you escape early it still shows it. Not only that, but eventually the cops will ignore you and you cant go in the safe house because "Cop Search", breaking the game and forcing you to restart to your previous file. Thats one of them thats rare.

Story: At first when you play this game, it feels like theres a story behind it. Making the game more interesting further. Then as you go through the past hours, you realize later theres no actual ending in this game. Its endlessly selling drugs. Whether the devs left this intentionally since due to being a simulator game or left some stuff unfinished I dont know.

Gameplay: At first, its really fun. A little odd because no guns or even cops shooting at you which instead they use tasers on you if close enough. But as time passes, it gets boring. As of this review, I am lvl 70. Maxed out my stats, and took over almost every city. Some were impossible for me because of certain reasons which I hope in the future developers would look into. I wont spoil it. Also, it gets tiring to run around the city handing out drugs constantly, even when you are a successful drug dealer.

Aside from these flaws, its an experience and enjoyed it. I would still recommend it, because this game is very reliable when it comes to killing time as well thanks to making the game endless. In case if you dont anything better to do. But on a personal note, it also feels like the game is unfinished. But regardless, I'd play it some other time if I am in a mood to play this game again.

At first I thought this might be a cheaply made game of questionable morals, and wasn't sure I was going to enjoy playing it, but I gave it a try because the new concept intrigued me and it was on sale.  I really wasn't disappointed!  It's a lot of fun!  It has all the ingredients of a fun, absorbing and playable game.   I also like the fact that it is more focused on stealth than violence.  There is no fighting or shooting of cops or anything like that. Stealth and logistics, build your business.   The bugs are minimal so far and the biggest complaint I have at this point is that the lab where you store, organize and craft your product is difficult to manage. The interface needs work so that the player can sort things out better like move containers around and such without following all these different menu modes, you should be able to just click and drag stuff.  Other than that, having fun.  Ok, enough, I'm going back to play some more.  There's so much to do!

6/10, Fun game, boring world, but some mindless fun. I personally enjoyed it very much. If you like simulation games, I think you'll enjoy it.

Unfortunately this game has done nothing but backslide since release.  Rather than add to the game play and depth of the game.  They have made the game more and more irritating and tiresome to play.   The best thing they did was add the ability to grow weed, except they added it at a point where most players don't bother with weed any more.

The map changes they made, made the game considerably less fun to play and much easier for the cops to catch you (in a game where the police already cheat like crazy, clip through walls and run at supersonic speed). Also why the locked gates everywhere that automatically re-lock in a few minutes.  Particularly as most of these gates would be even easier to climb than the fences.  They just closed the downtown off with them and turned it into a nightmare to navigate, especially while being chased by the police.  

Everyone sick of the generic lock-picking mini game that every sandbox game seems to need now.  All it does is add even more pointless busywork, and frustration when that gate you unlocked 5 minutes ago is locked again! 

Then they added the sewers upgrade, a good upgrade if it wasn't a crazy maze filled to the brim with more of these damnable self relocking locked gates. Seriously ENOUGH WITH THE DAMNED SELF LOCKING GATES! I should have to unlock them at most once a week preferably only once ever!  Not over and over and over and over, using the sad tired overused lockpicking minigame. To the point I just ignore them all, and the sewers too. 


Then came this new latest patch, which for me has just ruined this game.  They added a new area, great!, except it is locked up tight for some reason... ok, and you need keys... that can only be used x number of times..?!!  Seriously why do the keys magically run out of uses? Are they made out of crumbly metal and wear out? Is this a good game mechanic that make sense and help with immersion? NO it isn't, it is pointless busy work and a money sink.

Second they decreased the amount of time in a day, when there was already not enough time to get things done in the night. They did at least fix the completely broken reputation system so it doesnt instantly drain like it use to. Which is good at least.

Police heat now seems to be broken, I use to be able to deal unnoticed by dealing at night, now I find police cars and my heat way up doing the same thing.

They also made some changes to dealing where certain areas prefer certain drugs, and certain clients want certain drugs. The wealthier areas prefer the expensive drugs, the poorer the cheaper. Problem is, this is not how it works in the real world at all.  The two most expensive drugs in the game, cocaine and heroin are the most in demand drugs in the poorest areas of the american inner cities. Crack cocaine is an epedimic, and heroin is litterally everywhere, as are most of the other drugs. These changes are not how it works in the real world and the old system was in many ways better.

The most agravating changes were to the inventory. We are now tied to slots in backpacks etc, that can hold up to 20g each and yet keys (1kg) somehow too. this means when you make a 100 gram batch of your favorite drug, and break it down into the most common 1g and 2g varieties, you will have dozens of 10-20 packs in your backpack, and each backpack size can only hold so many packs. Which makes sorting through inventory to get deals ready pure torture, especially with the new time pressures.

You can't even trim back to 2 types of drugs any more because each client wants what they want, which leads to many identical bags holding vast little piles of drugs.

So ya, this game is in even worse shape than when it released. And the changes have taken away almost anything that made this game fun.


Anyways these are my suggestions to the developers to fix this game before it gets even more worse.

1. Fix the inventory system. A small backpack can easily hold 1-2kg of drugs, even if you broke it all down to 1 gram bags it can still easily hold 1-2kg of drugs. So drop the stack limits entirely please. 1 stack per weight type, per drug.

2. Either get rid of the locked fences and gates, or make it so you need to unlock them once every week, or once period. The lockpicking minigame is an overused mechanic and adds little to the game.

3. Make it a bit easier to escape the cops. The point of the game is to have a good chance of getting away. The cops should have stamina like we do, and run at reasonable speed, and stop being unexahustable terminators.

4. The keys for the new area should not have limited uses. Try coming up with a better mechanic, like maybe passcodes or bribery

5. We need ways of managing clients, ways to group them by district, ways remove them

6. I suggest making the drug drops only happen in the south part of the city. This is where the cartel we belong to lives, and it would add the challenge of having to move drugs from our area to the rest of the city.

7. We should not get heat at night unless chased by police, or arrested with drugs on us.

I give Drug Dealer Simulator a super apprehensive "recommend"... it starts great but fails to meet its potential as your business grows in scope. Giving it the thumbs up because I enjoyed my time with it but just be aware that this game will be a grind, and doesn't really have an ending. Below are my thumbs ups and grievances, which won't make sense unless you've played.

Where the game works (early-mid game):
-Running one-off deals with clients and mid-sized deals with your dealers, dodging the police
-Leveling up your reputation and expanding your lineup of products, upping prices
-Smuggling drugs across into Sector B of the map, which has a few different methods and all have their uses
-Using a knockoff Discord for keeping track of deals is fun, and I enjoy making the dead-drop runs

Where the game breaks down (late game):
-The quests and progression grind to a halt - the quests involving certain gangs feel half baked at best, incomplete at worst
-Reputation becomes meaningless after unlocking all zones because there's too many districts to maintain for no benefit
-Sector C is blatantly not finished
-The scale and frequency of orders grows to such a stupid level that it no longer makes sense for you to be responsible for pushing 400g of cocaine daily for a massive gang, supplying 10 dealers with drugs, and also still serving individual people when they message you
-Growing weed and mixing drugs is fun but serves basically no purpose other than scraping a bit more money, which serves no real purpose anyway, other than buying useless properties

Feel like they committed way too much time to the Growing / Mixing part of the game and not enough on having you run the business side of your operation. Having to manage your dealers (what they sell and where, scheduling them to avoid suspicion, having them help with growing/mixing efforts) and pushing large amounts of drugs to the city should be the late-game, not running around like you're the town's drug mule. 

As it stands, the late-game is the exact same as the start but 10x the customers, 10x the quantity, and way more hassle running around constantly for no further benefit. Doesn't exactly make you feel like you've conquered the drug dealing world!

Anyway yeah still recommend cause it was fun :)

this honestly seems like it would be a really bad game. the graphics are nothing special and it looks rough around the edges, and there are a lot of similar looking 'niche simulator' games around that really suck (barely any content, janky and buggy, basically just a cash grab). 

So if you saw DDS and thought it was just another barely functional simulator game, it is totally understandable. that's what I used to think. but this game is actually really, really fun. It has very tight and satisfying gameplay loops, the game mechanics are fun and satisfying, though sometimes lacking polish. and there is a surprisingly large amount of content to progress through, and you have alot of flexibility in when and how you progress. some of the things you can do: 

- you can cut and mix drugs to boost their profitability, or to increase or decrease how addictive and/or dangerous they are.
- customers can actually OD and die, which affects your reputation. there is alot of thought put into the different drugs and how addictive / profitable / dangerous they are.
- different customers have different 'quality' expectations, customers can get addicted which adds some interesting changes
- you can work with gangs, moving big quantities of product, same gameplay loop as regular selling but done in a different way.
- money is implemented in a fairly sophisticated and interesting way: you can only use cash for certain things, for many important things you need to use your bank account but depositing too much money is risky, so there's a whole money laundering system.
- you can rent properties all over the map, which provide bonuses and act as safe houses, and buy and place furniture and equipment in them.
- you can grow weed lol

there is a ton of great content in this game, it's completely worth the price, i'm still getting tons of fun out of it.

Yes - I have clocked a good amount of hours on this game, and might clock more, but let me be straight up - the game is completely grindy. Bear with me - making a grindy and repetitive game that is coincidentally fun is possible (I am looking at you, the entire MonHun franchise). 
But these devs have failed at it. Whatever content they add only serves as a decoration to the lack of story and depth of progression, and fun in this game. 
Real life criminals and Drug Lords like Pablo Escobar will not run around themselves just to deliver 2g of stuff to a druggie 5 miles away. So shouldn't you, because you eventually become so large that you should bother yourself with management, and bribing the authorities, and not with doing small orders.
This game has you hire dealers - clients that order more and redistribute your dope. How about instead of them doing fictive, non-existent clients, you can assign your real clients to these dealiers by drag and dropping them?
As a virtual drug lord, I want to bother with management, with luxury, and with progression - and not with doing the exact same thing over and over again, only in slightly varying scenarios.
And did I forget to mention - the trailer that the devs had for this game is entirely different from what we have in the end. Am I saying that this is bad? No. Between the production of the trailer and the final game, things can change. But lets face it - with the various UI elements, the trailer wanted to present itself as legit gameplay - but was not the gameplay that we got.
The NPC animations are lame, the story is nonexistent after level 20. The game still has game breaking bugs, which have not been fixed. How hard is it to fix a couple of typos in the game? Definetely a lot easier than spending time adding things literally no one has asked for.

This game is fun as a timekiller, but do not expect to feel yourself like a drug lord, since you are literally dependent on one character to keep your business going (Eddie)

epic

Update 2/2022: 
Big update that adds more areas and content, overhaul on the dealers and large gang order. Good for the most part. You actually have some late game stuff to do now, being nearly absent once you started making huge deliveries to the gangs. Those have been drastically scaled back and not making 10s or 100s of thousands at one go. 

There's plenty of bugs and issues around, but the bottom line is that it's still worth the price for the entertainment that's there. Plus they are actually putting out decent free content for what is now a 2 year old relatively low budget game. So for asking price or on sale well worth it.

I've got a bit of a mixed review. I'm recommending because I think that for the amount of money this game costs, I've already gotten my money's worth. 60 hours is more than most AAA single player games, so for less than $20, it's a deal. It is entertaining. 

On the flip side, once you've hit the mid game and have made several gang drug deliveries, it starts to get stale. A lot of the drug mixing complexity is wasted, because once you have a decent mix, you just replicate that. The gang deliveries are worse in this respect, since there's no addiction mechanic, I just mix it to the lowest acceptable percentage with the cheapest additive. 

It would be great if there was a mid to late game management aspect. It seems pointless and can be frustrating to continue making 2-5 gram deliveries as a street level dealer just to maintain respect levels when you're already making hugely profitable gang deliveries. There's not a drug dealer or businessman alive that would continue wasting time on $20 transactions when they're making five to six figure transactions almost daily. It would be much more rewarding to pass off the small customers to a network of dealers that handle everything, but you have to make sure they're supplied and not getting busted or ratting on you when they're unhappy. Add some depth to the dealers. Maybe they specialize in a certain drug, maybe they're skimming money, maybe they're a police informant, etc. 

Lot's of room to grow, since the core gameplay is solid. A sequel or large DLC with deeper mechanics and the ability to leave the small stuff behind would be great.

Really stepped up the game with this last update.
 Have you ever wondered what the drug trade is like in the U.S.? What if it was presented to you by someone who has never been there, but definitely knows communism/socialism?  You don't really have any other choice....

Y'know, this game is oddly addictive. The premise is you..well..deal drugs. Whether it be weed, mdma, crystal, amp, shrooms, coke, lsd, and you can cut these drugs and make your own mixes to try and profit as much as you can. With dealing comes money, and with money comes getting new hideouts to grow and produce in. You can fully customize your hideouts also, just watch out, too much bad activity and the DEA is on your ass.

It's fun, it's a bit of a thrill being chased by the police while carrying all kinds of shit cause you feel confident in your drug dealing capabilities. You can't defend yourself at all so you have to play sneaky around the cops. There's a very light RPG element in the form of XP, respect, gangs, and leveling your characters skills up.

For a $20 game I'd say it's worth the money.

Very Addicting. No puns intended. Sneaking around all the time avoiding patrols, making money, the creativeness from making your own recipes. A lot of fun. However. There is no endgame. There are no new features, even when the quest reward says so. The end game is repeating what you've done, but with bigger numbers. There are no new things to buy, there are no new drugs to get or mixers to try out. There are so many things that would help this game, but frankly it's been too long. It feels forgotten even though some people swear its not. It's still super buggy; even having been out for this long. It took me 3 different game saves to manage to progress without my save being unplayable due to some bug. After finally getting the game to work as intended; I found it relatively easy to make money and progress, which of course is fine, it just takes time. But the biggest problem is there is no big reveal. There is no breaking the ceiling. There is no better equipment, or new map, or new people. There's just the game as it is. If it ever gets updated - Worth a play. But as it is right now in its current state - it's simply not worth putting time or commitment into.

Hmm, ok so this is my first review of a steam game, so bear with me.

To start off, I would say there is some playability in this game and you can get your money's worth if you wanted to role play as a drug dealer for a little while. The problem is though that after you get used to the gameplay loops, there really isn't much to offer in terms off story/end game products, you're just dealing drugs just to deal, no real rewards to compliment the work you put in, which is unfortunate because there def is a solid foundation to this game.

Pros:
-Solid gameplay loops

-Good time waster

-Nice challenge that encourages different methods of play

Cons: 
-I think it's still in early access with no clear timeline on when/if it will ever be finished

-The updates progessively make the game more unstable/unplayable (I stopped playing after they took out a control option without bringing it back after mentioning it to a developer over a year ago)

-Little incentive to continue on after unlocking all the drugs

-A.I can be a little wonky


While I do hope the Devs can turn this project around, I think there's not much left to offer with this game and would only recommend if you wanted to try something new and you have a disposable income. Otherwise, pass.

Update 1/19/22:  So far, multiple safe houses owned:  zero things lost after saving, quitting and restarting the game over several days.  It is good to be back in business.  My recommendation goes from not,  to absolutely.

After 12 hours, I had an issue, and I went to read that it's an issue that hasn't been fixed since its acknowledgment over a year ago.  The issue is, once you purchase an additional facility like an apartment or warehouse, and you purchase furniture and all the shabang that goes with....these things may "disappear" for no apparent reason (such as a raid).  A chunk of my 12 hour time went to raising the funds to purchase minimal equipment to get the 2nd safehouse up and running only to have the entire room and the lab contents purchased for it (not even placed onto a workstation) gone....all but the secret floor/wall panel, which had nothing in it to begin with.  I had a good bit of fun running around and playing this title.  I feel gut-punched to know that I can't, in good faith, continue playing knowing chunks of my progress can just disappear and this issue hasn't been resolved by the developer.  They must've cashed in on massive amounts of real drugs and well....they're like gone, man!  Fuckin' gone!

Update:  I probably should've done more research on how this game was advertised when released and what occurred the weeks after.  I feel like most of the positive reviews come from library collectors that gave this title a few good hours and called it great and moved on to the next flavor of the list.  From my observations, when DLC/expansion stuff, albeit free, is released and they don't come with game-breaking bug fixings (here's looking at you Crossroads Inn makers and ChodeScratch), I still feel cheated.

EDIT: The date is 09/01/2022. I have changed my review to "no". Do NOT purchase this game. IT IS A MONEY GRAB. The "company" producing this game has endlessly neglected this title and has falsely advertised promises they did not keep. Just look at the comments on their "community" posts and you will understand the general census of how people feel how this developer. This is purely an asset flip, taking premade assets, making false promises and taking as much money as possible then ditching the game completely. These devs wholeheartedly do NOT deserve your hard earned money, please spend it elsewhere and save yourself the disappointment.

The good: 
I'm only 14 hours in but I managed to hit level 15, a goal we all wish to get to for that sweet sweet ganja growing. Anyways, the game is pretty damn solid. Good mechanics, a nice amount of frustrating, just enough to keep you wanting to flip more packs like the real g you are. I can endlessly flip drugs of my choice with nothing forced upon me, the freedom is truly fun. Whipping up some amphetamine and drying your big bags of weed as you grow your empire, what more is there to love? The voice acting is pretty fresh and the accuracy is much enjoyed. It takes some time to get the hang of the best ways to do things, but once you do you're running around constantly with a plan that could change at any given moment. The system of heat works well and I love having to tone it down and not supply anyone but my closest dealers in order to avoid heat but still keep the income rolling in, a thoroughly realistic experience.

The bad:
The game is however lacking in some areas. The map is fairly confined and in one 8 hour sitting I had unlocked the whole area. There's no use of vehicles or at minimum a peddle bike, meaning you HAVE to run everywhere and so does everyone else. The idea we're locked in by the government with constant unrealistic checkpoints can eventually get quite dull and feels like an excuse to do less work, since we already know how big game worlds can be in 2020. In my opinion, multiplayer in this game would be a breathe of fresh air in many ways, given that there would be a bigger world to accompany it and things like vehicles in order to really feel like I can flex my big cash gains. A server-based multiplayer (where only one player can claim a property, other players can band up or be rivals etc. and everything saves on the server) or co-op mode with saves would be great and really give us some greater goal. I thoroughly enjoy the messaging app, but it seriously needs to work on the phone rather than just the laptop, role-playing as a drug dealer who doesn't really use his phone is a bit... naff. 

In conclusion, the core mechanics are really sick. There isn't another game quite like it and it can feel fairly addictive at times. This game is essentially what GTA V is missing, but then it's also missing a vast open world like GTA V. Quite a frustrating reality from someone who was so ready to properly slang drugs in the GTA Online world just to be horribly disappointed by Rockstar Games. I just really need a way to flex my money, starting out walking and buying better and better transport as I go along. Being able to visit other cities and not live in a dystopian universe where there are walls surrounding the city and the ability to really experience the high life and get out of the ghetto. So that's it, all this game lacks is a sense of accomplishment and a big open world to explore.

The game is small. It lacks polish, doesn't really have strong endgame content, and could use a few ways to spend your money other than buying more drugs to sell.

That being said, DDS is an addicting (no pun intended) and brilliantly designed resource management sim with an elegantly simple and plainly fun stealth system.  One of my favorite elements of the game is a great example of some of its most engaging qualities. Being outside at night will get you arrested, if you get caught, but clients pay you more for delivering during those hours. This presents an optional challenge to the player that is not only extremely rewarding, but also forces you to engage with one of the strongest design elements the game has to offer; the map. 

Police patrols become mostly predictable a few hours into the game if you are making note of where you see them most often. However, the patrols adapt to where you are most active during the day, effectively zeoring in on areas where you have some of your most accessible clients early in the game. This will force you to think on your feet when making a delivery and running into an unexpected patrol, forcing you to find other routes to stay punctual, which is something your clients make note of. 

Your knowledge of the different twists, turns, nooks and crannies of the map will expand as your reach across it does. There are several unlockable hideouts across the game which can serve basically as a drug lab or storage space, but you are also (effectively) safe from police inside of them, which can also come in handy if you find yourself running from them, which will also put your map knowledge to the test. 

This game is far from perfect, but it has some incredible and practical ideas that really make it easy to look past its minor flaws that have a particular indie-studio-charm. The game is still regularly receiving support from the devs and I'm excited to see how it grows and evolves. It has so much untapped potential and it stands to be an even better and more fun game than it already is, which is honestly just fantastic. This game is easily worth double what it's listed for on Steam.
