Honestly I like this game but it runs like a brick for me, especially in the tunnels (when it's raining).  Why is it even raining in the tunnels?  I really like the concept and the gameplay but it's rough around the edges.  Here's some areas I think you should improve:

- Disable rain in the tunnels (and generally optimize this game for minimal graphics settings).
- Improve the awkwardness of the drug interaction/bagging process.  It's okay to have more than one hotkey (e) to use to interact with objects in the game.  A very simple improvement would be to allow users to hit "enter" on their keyboard instead of having to manually drag and click the mouse on the "confirm" button when the game asks you how many grams of something you want to transfer, but I think you can do so much more here.  The entire workbench interaction thing is totally unintuitive.
- Allow us to move furniture between outposts
- Give us something satisfying to spend our money on - gambling, clubs, collectibles, upgrades, moving out of this rundown city, a mansion, etc.
- Consider balance changes to the respect and sales mechanics.  I'm pretty late game with all areas unlocked, and it just feels like a chore getting everyone drugs and trying to prevent respect from dropping -- additionally, there is no way to get bonuses in certain areas, like Bad Asia.

Again, I do like this game, but for $20 I would expect more polish.

87 HOURS UPDATE: the game certainly got repetitive, there's no end-game, is unfinished, the teaser showcases game elements that are just not there, the developers don't update it or even fix its bugs and their PR comms are vague attempts to pretend there's some movement (where there's obviously none). This game massively improves when bought half-priced.

---
Surprisingly addictive and with more depth than I expected. The base mechanics are stealthy fetch quests, a neighbourhood reputation system, drug design and lab (base) building. The map is large, keeps some secrets and allows traversal progression by picking locks, unlocking areas and finding alternative routes. Regarding drugs, how you mix them results on losing clients over time, turning them into addicts or their death. There's also a money laundering system to allow you acquire property (spaces and equipment).

The worst thing I've seen so far is difficulty and repetitiveness. While I find it easy on the highest difficulty I also suspect the game is keeping some surprise for later. The next worst thing are the whinny comments from the community (some famous Youtuber played it on his channel and attracted attention). Please, note this is an indie game, the company isn't CDPR and the pricetag is quite affordable (low for the fun I'm having, TBH). I'm hooked to this game and considering starting my own business IRL =)

Hey don't trust people who said this game has crypto miner. I play the game in GTX 1070 and my usage CPU is 30~50%, GPU is 60~70% all the time, max setting in 1440p. 

Very hesitate about buying this game due to I see a lot of drama around this game, like the devs release the trailer doesn't match with the game content (some content in trailer doesn't exist in an actual game ..yet.)

But after bought this game, yo, it's really fun and I enjoy to playing this game a lot. Drama aside, this game still has plenty of content that can keep you playing for hundred of hours. Even if the dev doesn't update more content, I don't even mad about that. Also, I didn't see any bug so far, only one glitches that when the police searching me and I run, they beat the sh i t out of me, then the text "police is searching" will be stuck on the screen. So here is the sum up: 

- Game work great in my specs (1440p max setting) no overheat, no max usage.
   i5-8500 3.0GHz 
  16GB of RAM 
  GTX 1070 8GB 
  SSD

- The game loop came very soon, or should I say, this is what it is. 
- Random generated NPC and quest. 
- Some NPC go home at night and go out at day time.
- Story is okay. Not much to say. 
- You can choose your client, like see a chick walking on the street, gift her some drug and vola! you has a new client. 
- Depend on how you mix your drug (yes you can create your own drug and sell it), it might make your client become a loyal one, or it can kill your client, like too much toxic in your drug because your drug contains 70% of washing powder.
- Day night cycle. 
- Weather systems 
- Buy and decor your house/hideout. 
- Police raid, if you do thing too loud, the police will notice and will soon launch the raid operation to your safe house, you have nothing to protect your safe house except gather as much stuff as you can and escape before the police arrives. 
- You have to planning your way, because the police patrol can appears anywhere, anytime, like even outside of your door.
- You can climb over wall, some people complain that they can't jump and run at the same time, well, the devs has fixed it, I can run and jump at the same time. 
- And more stuff that I have not discover yet.

This is a great game for those of you who can appreciate stealth, logistics, and risk management. Start from nothing, and slowly and carefully build your drug empire across the city. With nearly 300 hours on record, i would say the replay-ability is there; different drugs to experiment with, different difficulties to test your skills, and the drive to expand your territory and collect more cash!

There are faults in the game including spelling errors and occasional bugs, but the dev team is very active and releases updates and bug fixes as quickly as they can. Overall 9/10 which will likely increase as updates and expansions are released.

The concept of the game can be fun and I enjoyed a lot of it but it really needs to be seen as an early access title at this point. There's a lot of content missing and being promised, with not a lot of great comms from the developers at this point. If they would just be a bit more transparent and give an actual road map instead of infrequent 'sneak peak of upcoming update' posts every few months then I don't think the community would be as upset as they currently are.

Almost 200 hours into this game I decided I need to update my review. The first review I left was in the very early days of this game and there was an issue with lagging making the game unplayable. That has long since been fixed. There have been updates to the world, some of the mechanics, and polishing of game play making it pretty amazing. I actually restarted my game now that I have a better understanding of the game and how to maximize my profits by mixing and stretching my products. So I can't speak to later mechanics of the game (raids, storing money in gold bars etc) but what they've done so far is a perfect balance of challenge and simulation enjoyment. There's enough of a grind to keep you trying but not enough of a grind where it feels like the same thing over and over and no leveling up. There is a good size playing area, and different ways to navigate from point A to point B. There is miscellaneous trash/debris/graffiti that the area feels lived in and realistic, although the concrete walls that separate the north from the south are a bit out of place (they remind me of barriers we used in Iraq) but I understand their purpose so it's not a deterrent for me. The addition of usable tunnels make the experience more immersive but be careful to remember how to get around, it gets disorienting. Overall, I'm very happy with my purchase and have gotten my monies worth 10x over and still have a long way to go. Do yourself a favor and see if you can be a king pin.

I learned more from this game than i ever could in school..

You start out in Jesse Pinkman's position in the first episode of Breaking Bad. That's as far as you get. You just sell the same dry weed to the same neighbors in the same ghetto neighborhood. You don't move up in the world. You do not become Stringer Bell.

You prepare baggies of drugs in a lab in a first person shooter format. Like Skyrim except without the alchemy menu, just picking up small herbs and mixing with with other small objects in first person.

Cops will search you without a warrant just because you walk near them. They only stop you. They do not stop literally anyone else. If it is nighttime, they will stop you on sight for just for being out at night. They do not stop anyone else even though it's a city-wide curfew (unexplained in the lore).

Moving drugs from your inventory to another person's is ridiculously hard. You can't make a 4g bag of drugs so you have to only use two 2g bags. You have to control-click to sell any amount other than "all" and you have to use a slider to select how many you want. Most people just want 1 bag. Nobody wants all bags. The only people who want more than one bag are people who want 4g. So that's just a difficulty built into the game. It's a built-in puzzle to seperate out who needs 4g of something which will require special attention. If you could somehow find the technology to create a 4g bag, everyone would only want 1 bag.

Gas stations are legally open for business all night but apparently it is illegal to walk to one.

There are no cars. Just thought that was funny.

Customers can get addicted to weed. Weed addicts will pay more for your weed. And they all know how to use encrypted messaging on private servers just so they can buy 2 grams of weed from their next-door neighbor.

This game is a 14 year old's idea of what a drug dealer is after watching 8 Mile. The dialogue is hilariously unrealistic. This game is nothing but a glorification of drugs in an attempt to appear edgy to young people. If you want to grow, play Stardew Valley. If you want to run from the cops, play GTA. If you want to sell baggies of dry dusty weed to five customers, just do it in real life. It's not that hard. That's why this game is so stupid. What's the point of simulating what I can easily do. Anybody can do this. It's literally easier in real life because you don't have to stick with an FPS format to make baggies of drugs on a tiny table. Wake me up when someone makes a game where you can become a heroin kingpin in West Baltimore selling testers to desperate broke junkies and siphon millions of dollars out of the projects. I want to bribe politicians to give me cheap real estate. I want to be the reason corrupt politicians don't get investigated. I want to publicly murder witnesses.

This game is a lil janky, personally I wouldn't pay full price from playing it. I do enjoy the game, the loop is decent so far and there is a lot of personalization to what you can do in the game. I'm excited to see what it has left for me to explore.

DDS has a very solid game loop. During the day you order and pick up drugs, mix drugs with additives so they are safer, stronger and/or more addictive, spray-paint your logo, and give out free drugs (testers). At night you complete deliveries to customers and dealers, and pick up money from dealers, though this is done during a curfew, The game expects you to only commit crimes at night, which keeps exposure to law enforcement low. Police patrol most areas, and will sometimes search you during the day (based on your exposure) and will always search you after police hours, which is basically a curfew.

You can also eventually unlock the ability to sell large amounts of product wholesale to gangs, which is very profitable depending on which product it as. The early game takes a bit to build up, starting with a basic apartment which cannot be furnished beyond a single worktable and only two drugs available for sale. Eventually you can unlock ten total drugs (amphetamine, marijuana, ecstasy, crystal meth, cocaine, heroin, fentanyl, dmt, lsd, and mushrooms), safe-houses of various sizes, as well as pharmaceuticals and other additives for mixing drugs.

You can mix any drugs together, though some have to be processed through various equipment which is unlocked through leveling up. There's also a simple skill upgrade system as well which make it easier not to be spotted by police, provides extra pockets, and other things. Drugs and additives have various strengths, strengthening of mixes, toxicities, and addictiveness. Balancing these things through experimentation with new formulas helps keep the game interesting, as addicted clients buy more product, but are also more likely to overdose.

The game is an excellent return for your money. I'm near the end of my first playthrough at the time of writing this and am very happy with my purchase. There are still additional features being added, and some bug fixes and quality of life improvements are badly needed, but overall it's a great game. A third sector will be added soon, and hopefully more drugs as well as more additives, as there are only four pharmaceutical and five non-pharmaceutical additives. I'd love to see more drugs such as crack, pcp, cannabis concentrates, and others added, in addition to things like caffeine pills and other common real life drug additives. It would also be great to be able to grow and buy precursor materials so we can go full Breaking Bad in game.

Oh and please add the Dark Web! There's already a docks right there on the map, we could just run over there, get past patrols, and drop it on a boat. That'd give more options for wholesaling other drugs, which is desperately needed to make the endgame more interesting and allow for more specialization. As is I can handle selling all drugs (albeit only in sector A, almost maxed out on dealers), two growhouses with 75 or so plants, processing that marijuana by adding additive to bulk the weight for wholesale, trying out new mixes, and moving things around. I'd love to do future playthroughs where I can specialize in any drug and produce it from farm to table.

If you like business games, like simulation games (with a tiny bit of jank, admittedly) and don't mind the subject material, which is taken seriously for the most part aside from a few memes, and doesn't actually display any drug use onscreen (though you can sample your own products), then check this out and pick it up.

You will likely be able to waste a lot of time on this game, if:
- You played Dope Wars in the 90s, or
- You get wired before you're tired enough to sleep,
- You find running numbers and peeking around corners therapeutic.

However, if you aren't specifically looking for exactly this game, you should wait for a solid discount.

[b]Annoyances:[/b]

- Not all Walls are Climbable, and it is not always obvious which. When running from Police, try to favour paths you have taken before, and be wary that occasionally the mid-height wall with a flat top simply will not allow you to jump over.

- The Workstations are a little fiddly. If you prefer a high DPI mouse, you may benefit from a DPI Switch, so that you can lower the sensitivity when using the Workstation - Object Menus require you to aim at the object while navigating the Menu and if your cursor slips off it the Menu will reset when you get it back up. Also there is no quick-key for Packaging Product, so I hope your Mousewheel works!

- Outdoor Plants are a lot more RNG than you may think! Even if you find a spot to grow something which is not visible from any road or Police Patrol path, your plants will still Despawn over time! IE, Police Officers do not actually have to see a Plant to Despawn it. I recommend waiting to buy Indoor Growing Equipment, but if you do use Outdoor Seeds, make sure to tuck each plant in the tiniest, most obscure corners you can, EG: In a backyard, far from a road, at the edge of a map, in a fenced area between a shed and a dumpster. A spot fulfilling all these stipulations might make it to full growth. I just watched 10 plants which were very well hidden disappear before my eyes, and there is nothing you can do to stop them.

- As far as I can tell, there's no way to add mass to MJ with Sugar ;P

[b]Other Tips[/b]

Bag Capacity is a little more strict than you might expect. You can't stuff as much into a bag as you might in real life, so remember that it is a game, and the inventory makes some concessions to improve the challenge and organisational demands on the player. If you are spending more than say, $300 on an Order, get yourself a Medium Backpack from the Gas Station first, it takes a lot less than a Kilo of anything to max out your starting bag!

Try to get some property quickly. I waited and saved for better properties, but even poor locations and facilities help maintain your Rep in a neighbourhood, and waiting has made it quite annoying for me, as I have to buy paint and spray tags constantly.

[b]TL:DR[/b]

As I just got this game, I am still playing it quite intently, but even after the honeymoon period is over, I believe this game will continue to be a great way to kill time, or ride out that period between being too tired to really do anything important, but too awake to actually go to bed.

The game doesn't give me enough variation to keep the buzz of playing. It needs more content involved, not just new areas. As others have said, it gets very repetitive by about level 7.

Pros:

 - Combining ingredients is fun. Coming up with concoctions and different ratios then selling them on is great! A little bit of washing liquid never hurt anyone after all...

Cons:

 - Buy drugs, mix, sell to client, run home and avoid cops. Repeat. 
 - Base building is really poor, I'd rather they took this out and just furnish the hideouts for us. It's painful
 - The game has no memory function to show recipies you've tried and the outcome of those. This is a feature that's essential if we are going to be making our own versions
 - Should also be a way of unlocking recipies so you have an idea of what does work.
 - Graphically it's really poor. I know this isn't a multi-million pound game, but it does need an update..

There's a lot of stuff that I like, dislike, and want to see. Before I get into any of them, I just want to state that my current opinion is positive.

- Things I like -
: Main voice actor is flawless. Could not have picked better.
: Good loop.
: Good progression.
: Mixing drugs is pretty damn fun.

- Things I don't like -
: The game is unplayable without the wiki, and unfortunately the wiki is really bad. There are several parts of the game that just need a little information to them. A lot of new players have no idea how to package product and get frustrated, make that a mandatory part of the tutorial.
: We need way more additives, categories of additives, and a rebalance of their stats.
: Mouse movement feels gelatinous.
: Compass is almost always broken.
: While never mentioned in any dialogue (that I've heard so far) there are some buildings that play music with racial slurs. Really wish I could turn that part off.

- Things I want -
: Employees of any kind.
: Cop bribes. (maybe based on reputation?)
: Weapons to fight off said cops.

- The one thing I really want -
: Non-cop threats. You can bet your ass I want to see a serial killer.

Alright gamers I never write reviews but this game makes me feel like I have to.

This game is good. The main gameplay loop is enjoyable, I find myself playing it mindlessly while watching Critical Role.
The game gets really easy after like level 15 because at that point you've unlocked Cocaine which is the most profitable drug in the game. You get to the point around level 18-20 where your money is meaningless, basically a DDS billionaire. You can buy every property and every object/furniture like 80 times over just like Pablo ;). The devs are pretty inconsistent with their updates and they havent had any real new gameplay content since the Weed growing update LAST spring right after the release of the game. The most recent Harty Pard update adds new drugs which are pretty well not worth your time because they're no where near the level of Cocaine in terms of margin. I find myself moving kilos of coke, not worth my time to deal in dime bags of acid and weed. All in all its a fun game and I enjoy it still BUT this game needs more gameplay or story and better comms between the player base and devs in regards to updates. Community modding support would be dope as well. I would say only buy this on sale given the real content in the game but i've more than got my 22.79 out of it. cheers

[i] EDIT (9.2021):
Yup, here we are 1ish year later. Just gonna keep it short this time. Abandon all hope that this game will ever be something similar to what was promised in the early promotions. 

Updates, while still happening, are few and far between, and when they do arrive, they are A) either something very minimal, barely notable micro tweaking, maybe even an occasional QOL feature if you are lucky or B) Something a bit bigger, which the devs have worked on for a very long time, but instead they are often completely pointless features no one asked for and which dont contribute to actually evolving this game, in really any direction.

And on top of that, the devs really like to use this games NEWS/UPDATE feed to promote other games, games which have a very similar vibe as DSS of promising great things, but ending up pretty barebones, games which officially "have no association with this games developer or publishers", even though the patterns are suspiciosly similar.  Yup, nothing shady at all with that...

(ORIGINAL REVIEW, posted shortly after the game released on steam)
 Note: This is just gonna be a very short warning to everyone considering purchase instead of an actual review.
Playtime by the time of writing this review: 29 hours. [/i]

Super-shortly said: Avoid for now, but it has lot of potential. The developers utilized a very scumbag approach to marketing, so I recommend caution whenever dealing with products/games from these developers. 

A bit more information: So I bought this game the first day of launch, I`ve never heard of it before, but it SEEMED really cool. I even tried the demo before purchase and was quite impressed with it, so I bought the game. However; Now I can confirm that the store page at the time of this titles launch, was a prime example of FALSE ADVERTISING. 

At the release date; this store page contained different information from what it contains by the time of writing this review: It had a trailer which clearly showed: 1. that the player would be able to grow their own drug-plants 2. A fighting scene showing the player getting punched by a civilian person and 3. The ability to "PARTY!", in the form of laying by a pool and shooting some glass bottles etc.  

Almost 2 weeks later of launch, NONE of the above-mentioned 3 features are currently present. Instead we have a game which is far from complete ( lacking content, technically "rough around the edges" etc) and should be labeled as an EARLY ACCESS-title. 

(But they removed those lying trailers and GIFS from the store page, so they did something right at least.)

However, it is IMPORTANT TO NOTE: that the developers are actually still working on this game and are planning to add more features over time, so the game will get better with enough time. 

But I still cant forgive that dirty marketing tactic at launch day, so Im gonna leave a THUMBS DOWN.

I realise this game has been kindly donated to us by the publishing equivalent of a pump and dump scheme (playway) but I believe it is necessary to note that whoever has decided to leave this game out to dry and not actually care to finish it is probably making a huge mistake. There's a reason out of the gazillion games these guys have published this one has seen a great deal of success unpolished as it may be. Because it's built on the solid foundation of an excellent gameplay loop, and would need just a couple of tweaks and additions (most notably: a functioning end game) to be actually palatable for a broader audience. I realise there is about 200 people playing this game at any given time, and as such, it might aswell be left for dead at this stage - but had something be done about it earlier, riding the high of youtube and twitch creators tuning in and checking out the game for it's unique premise I am sure something excellent and well selling could have come of it.

TL;DR: I'm actually kinda glad your laziness is biting you in the ass at the end of the day, as whatever success this game has found in the past is more attributable to sheer luck than any actual game developing and publishing skills you guys might possess.

This game is a like/dislike. Yes, I say I'd recommend it, but I'd like the devs to keep working on it; which I hear is about fallen out of. The experience I've had so far, was worth the price (entertained me for over a week), and if you've ever played a gmod roleplay server with drugs, this kind of sparks that interest, single-player, keep in mind. So I guess I'd say it's my own personal gmod drug roleplay with day/night cycles (and time skip), me vs the fuzz.
   The game starts off slow, is always repetitive, and until you can manufacture your own goods is where it really starts to pick up. You start off in your one apartment, every level you can use to advance your skills, and will probably be searched a LOT in the beginning. You don't unlock growing weed until level 15, and just to get there can take a while, from my experience. Your sales quantities aren't that much, nor are your amount of customers at the time.
   The further along you get - meaning, the more you can feel immersed just running around being a dealer, repetitively - the more houses become available to purchase and customize the interior, more people to meet and their drugs, more dealers available for you with bigger deals. Constant cash flow. Your exposition level is really affected in later game - do most deals at night, whether be cash delivery or contraband.
   It is nice when your customers want to become your dealer. Ultimately, I gotta say - they know a lot of crackheads. Some bought MJ and Amp when they were customers. Turn into dealers and buying meth by the buttload...
   My own interests are drawing me into  1) having a marijuana grow op - with a house nearby - CHECK.  2) Think I still need to meet said gang for their drugs to manufacture anything else - and have a house for each diff drug op. If the devs put more into the game, I could do  3) set up a fake drug house to get raided in and have a shootout with the fuzz

+++Like seriously, a book of recipes would be awesome. From mixing to manufacturing. The works. I thought growing weed was fun, and then being able to crystalize it, but that's really no good to any of the people on the streets for anything; it's just used to cut and mix with other crystal drugs - or powder, if powdered types are used. I thought it would have been awesome to 'sprinkle' the crystals on the weed itself, selling a higher potency bag of MJ, making them want more all the time(?)

You are a drug dealer...dealing drugs, buying it from MY MAN EDDIE. Selling it to Clients. It's a big map, much to do and the story is fantastic. Just a bit hard and complicated to make custom drugs, would be nice with a like book of drugs you could buy to help with recipies and such. 

Would definetly recommend 10/10

This game is dope!! Literally! 

You can sell drugs, mix drugs, organize them into little baggys. 
You can run from the cops, and start your own grow house and even hire people to deal under you.
10/10 great simulator!

The game idea is very good, but the game gets boring and repetitive after a few hours. I've got about 20 hours and some mechs made me decide to uninstall it for now. 
1) Dealers are "big buyers", that's it. 
2) You must keep a certain level of respect in a territory (by yourself and all the time). 
3) Once you decline an order, that junkie is gone. 
4) Junkies having O.D's with good product. 
5) No car (WTF?)

I could keep going... The main point is: Game gets very, very, very, very, very, repetitive because you have to keep "redoing" stuff, not only whe you are a small time dealer, but acctually all the time.  Can't designate a dealer to "Area A" or "Area B", it's all random and out of control.

This game speaks to me as I have a Dutch girlfriend, and will be moving to the Netherlands. Now I will be ready for that, at least...

Anyways! Drugs! Yay! There is not a lot to this game, but it is satisfying to pull off the things you can do!
You start of by selling weed and speed. Then you unlock more areas after getting respect in your current area, leveling up, then you can get dealers who will sell for you and so on... It's a simple game, but it does what it is designed to do.

You can mix drugs to make them more potent, or so I have heard (Not that far yet), thus enabling you to get people addicted to your stuff so that you always will have orders coming in. 

Be warned: This game is about drugs and evading the police. If you do not like that combo, this game is not for you. This game is more for people who just wants a different kind of "simulator" game, and it is fun to kill time with.

Happy selling!

This game is another reason why I really think Steam needs to add a neutral button to the review. It felt like Thief Sim just in a different setting. There is nothing wrong with this game in terms of glitches, bugs, or gameplay. It's fun and challenging. However, it suffers from the same massive drawback that Thief Sim suffers from and that is that there is zero replayability. This has even less replayability than Thief Sim though. At least in Thief Sim, it will take you a long time to clean out every house. Here is literally the boring grind over and over again. I like that instead of Thief Sim, it's infinite what you can do in this game but it renders it boring after a while. Also only other knock I can give this is the perk system is absolutely awful. The cops will find drugs on you and will spot you even if you have stealth and illusionist maxed out. Only runner and stamina work and are remotely useful. Salesman does nothing in letting you raise your prices. Also one other knock I can give is, this game expects you to know the street names of every drug and so I lost clients and delayed progression accidentally. It never explains that or recipes for things and the spray painting and respects mechanics make absolutely zero sense. So honestly, this game is fun and a good challenge but there are many things you have to work around and it can get boring. I hit recommend because I do enjoy playing this but only get it if it's on sale. 6 out of 10.

An oddly deep and satisfying game a about being your friendly neighborhood hoodlum. 

In short, you are a low level drug dealer under the wing of a much larger cartel. Game play loop consists of ordering drugs to be smuggled into the ghetto, then selling those drugs. This snowballs, more money means more drugs, more drugs means more money. Eventually you can start hiring your own dealers and advance past petty, back alley exchanges and into the world of distribution. At a point, you can even start producing your own drugs, negating the cost of smuggling from the cartel. You'd think this would cause a conflict of interest but, evidently not.  For the most part its very well done. Everyone likes playing the bad guy every now and again. 

The game world centers around a T.R.A.P. Im not sure if the game ever explains what that stands for, if it did, my mistake. Essentially, its a ghetto where crims, addicts and society's refuse is dumped and kept under a watchful eye of a specialized police force. From what I can tell, anyway. 

There are some nagging complaints. Being early access this is of course subject to change and the dev seems to have an idea of what hes going for, so these complaints are more general nitpicks. The game at large seems to be headed in the right direction. 

First. Man, please use spellcheck. And Google. There are a gratuitous amount of spelling, grammar and general knowledge mistakes. Even drugs are spelled wrong. 

There is a large amount of safehouses available. But due to the small size of the map, most of these are of dubious use. For example, There is a safehouse directly across the street from your main one, and another in the back alley of that one. You can run north to south across the map in under a minute. East to west, stopping at the checkpoint, can be done in about a minute thirty. Its not a large map by any means, and thats fine. In fact, I prefer smaller, detailed maps than colossal empty ones. But when a district amounts to only one block, a dozen or so safehouses feels like overkill. 

The police are pushovers. They are very easy to spot at a distance, even at night. They look almost identical to the merc units from Farcry 3. Putting even a couple skill points into runner and stamina, turns the police from an obstacle, and into little more than an annoyance. 

The D.E.A. Never met them. Been a bad boy, even tried to get a raid to see what would happen. Nada. Had my exposure maxed out, multiple warnings that I was attracting too much attention and apart from a marginal increase in beat cops, nothing really happened. 

At the moment there is no endgame. Im sure this is 100% because its still in early access and it just hasnt been added or even thought about yet. As it stands, money is used to upgrade the business and rent and decorate safehouses but not much else. Again, this is more of a heads up than a real complaint. An endgame is coming, its just not here yet. 

Overall, quite happy. Ive already gotten my money's worth out of it. Pretty excited to see where it goes.

Rep is basically Spray the wall simulator. Your rep drops you have to spray a bunch of walls with 2-3 second "loading bar" just terrible MMO-like superficial mechanic.Nothing Reputable about spray painting a wall, IRL crims would laugh their ass off if you claimed it was cool.

There's nothing to do with your drug money but to buy more drugs and some furniture.  But reading those same damn messages from npc's and running to them for sales is just too lame.

Needs more story and dialog please, after that I would be interested to play this more. Guns and fighting cops etc would be a huge plus also.

So no, I wouldn't recommend this for now. And I kinda feel bad for that because there's so much potential. Needs more my summer car game kind of approach-ish stuff.

THIS GAME IS JUST AWESOME minor bugs here and there but that's to be expected in every game

Theres a lot going for this game but there are quite a few negatives. 

Firstly, there are a few bugs that can really screw you over. The biggest is you will all of a sudden freeze where you are and if you are carrying and theres police by, you're done. Another is I accidentally moved my mortar under the desk shelf and it vanished, never to be seen again. Theres no real tutorial on some of the equipment so its trial and error. Some customers will spawn near police cars so you can't deal to them and lose reputation. 

The sewers, The god dam sewers, who invented them? Firstly, there is no map. Luckily there is one online but even then it takes you many attempts to learn the sewers, I even had to jot down my own map. You end up losing clients wasting so much time down there and your reputation drops. The sewer lags if you run too much. The water slows you down and why make us keeping unlocking the gates? Its a pointless task. Apart from the rubbish sewers and the overpriced tunnel, there should be an option to build underground tunnels or have drug mules or something. The sewers nearly made me refund this game.

You can't move equipment from one hideout to another so you keep having to buy stuff every time you unlock new hideouts and think 'hey this is a better location'. This can start to become a bit of a pain and tiresome. 

When you reach dealers, you will find that occasionally one of their clients dies and its your fault...how....nothing wrong with the product, you just gave the client too much. This results in your products losing value and having to lower their price. 

Overall, the concept is great and the micro managing of drugs is fun. It can be a real rush when your walking along to sell and the cops catch you and you have to leg it. It can become a chore having to jump from sector A to B to deal as by the time you've done one, the reputation has dropped considerably in the other sector. 

If like me you enjoy simulation games with business involved, I'd recommend it on sale.

[Review Update 7/17/21]
After not playing this game for a while and seeing a few"Major Updates" come out for it, I decided to pick it back up. Sad to say, the Devs believe adding a few re-skins and a crude tunnel system are "major updates". This game, while fun to play at first, lacks in oh so many ways still. As this game has been out for well over a year now I doubt there will be an actual major update that addresses any of the issues. Maybe someone who actually cares what their fan base wants will make a copy cat game, but it is doubtful. 

At this point, I would actually drop my rating to a 3/10 as even the smallest of fixes is likely to be overlooked by the devs.

THE DEVS SEEM TO HAVE GIVEN UP ON THIS GAME.

Which is sad because it could be fun if they just fixed the minor stuff!!!

Reading through the Discussion channel is just months of people complaining about the same issues, and no resolve. 

First of all, this game has a lot of competing mechanics (competing for your time, not actual competition). When you let any one of these fall out of line you lose customers. Then, the amount of time you spend rebuilding that one area, the others go to crap.  

The games primary mechanic is a reputation factor. Your rep varies from area to area, faction to faction.  You increase your rep primarily by selling drugs (makes sense), and your rep drops over time. lower rep = less orders. The problem is, some of the areas are tiny, so you only get a few clients. And then on top of that, you can lose 50% of your rep in a few in game hours, even though you've filled every clients order. To top it off, If you sell during the day, it increase police presence and overall chance of being raided by the DEA. Raise that limit enough and making a small delivery without being caught is beyond difficult, then you lose clients, and rep, and then the game is just a pain. 

IMO the Rep feature needs a massive update, if not removal. 

Police. Look, I get it, It's a drug game; police will be involved. But the police are OP. The devs took weapons / fighting out of the game so all you can do is run. But you can only run so much before you run out of stamina. Now yes, you can level up stamina, but guess what, cops never run out of stamina. PLUS, they get tasers... Your only option is to get into one of your hideouts (which you have to buy but can only buy through the ATM which raises cop / dea presence when you deposit "dirty" money, and the only way to clean it is to give it to a guy who takes a 40% cut. So buying 1 property can take A LONG TIME). The hit box on the hideout doors is hard enough to hit while running, Forget about when youre in the dark and cant even see where the ground meets a wall....  And no matter the time of day, no matter your rep or your, for want of a better term, wanted level; if you're within eyeshot of police, youre getting searched, or... run. 

Border? So there's a wall that separates the two halves of the ghetto for no reason. There are 3 openings in the wall that are police checkpoints. You will get searched, so you cant cross over with anything illegal. There is a system of sewers you can travel through to avoid the police checkpoints, but, you cant bring any bags, so youre limited to the small quantities you can carry in your pockets. Theres also a "construction tunnel" that runs under the whole city. But you have to pay a worker a varying and costly amount to use it, so its not useful until late in game. You used to be able to throw your bags over the wall and collect them when you get to the other side, but the devs nerfed your throwing strength so you can only get it over a few select places if you're lucky enough to avoid cops and not have to attempt the throw 35 times. 

TL/DR: 
- Rep system is... Bad, forces you to have more areas, rep decays faster, cant keep rep high = less customers. So effectively the game forces you to lose customers.
- Cops are OP / annoying as all get out
- checkpoint wall is incredibly stupid game mechanic that was only annoying until devs nerfed it for no reason making it beyond stupid. 

4/10 - Could be much much better with just a little TLC but this game seems to be failing more and more each day so the devs appear to have given up.

I can't explain why I like this game. There isn't really even much of an actual game here- all you do is deliver drugs to people and avoid the police. The only challenges to the game are paying attention to your surroundings so you don't walk into cops, and keep track of how much product you have on hand. That's it. It's pretty much just fetch and delivery tasks over and over again with very little strategy involved. I think it just ticks all the boxes in my brain because it's such a unique concept of a game, maybe? It also stays believable in that you aren't some GTA goon who goes from a loser to millionaire overnight selling drugs, you go from a loser with a 400$ SSI check in his bank account to a loser with 2000$ in his bank account still living in the same shitty apartment you started in.

The concept is great, but I really feel like the devs hit the limitations of the engine very quickly and it shows. Anyways, if it's on sale for 10$ worth it if you want to try out something different.

So, It's an amazing game. It's so fun to play and I cant wait to play more! 
P.s. Its easy to get money and Rep ;)

If you want a chill game to spend an hour or so after work playing then this game is a decent choice, the sewer update, and the psychedelics update were great additions and add some interesting and fun content, the weed one eh take it or leave it. all in all i would give it a 8/10 for early gameplay so if you want to just mess around a bit then take this as a positive review. there is however a serious problem with the late game which is why i left a negative review, i cant detail it without massive spoilers so be warned if you continue reading.

**spoilers start here**

The beginning of the game is a blast, getting new drugs to sell, finding new ways to cut and mix them to maximize profit. all the new equipment upgrades you can buy and the new stores that open up as you play it feels like youre constantly advancing as a drug dealer, getting reputation with buyers, the two gangs, the cartel, and entire city blocks. however after all your hard work building up and finally getting that sought after gang introduction you almost immediately reach a point where the only thing worth doing is delivering either coke or meth to your respective gang. nearly everything else is a waste of time. you dont need to uphold rep because all it does is increase single buyers which you have progressed way past. you dont need to mix drugs because the time/benefit ratio to mixing 1500g is way too time consuming. you wont be selling anything other than either meth or coke so no formula experimentation. and the largest problem of all: what the hell am i supposed to do with $100,000? sure buy every property, but for what purpose? not wasting my time with weed. i guess i could store my thousand suitcases in there. the game comes to a dead halt. its not worth your time to do anything but gang missions, and why would you do them? theres nothing more to buy. the updates seem to be adding to the early game which is awesome! but what about the dead end? some decorative weapons like rifles or swords or some paintings or just anything to spend cash on would be great. or even mod support so the comunity can add things. hell add in strippers for all i care. just please add in something to do with my multitude of suitcases filled with soo much cash i cant even drop the cash to have my own money bed because the stack wont fit again.

**edit**
there is a painting shop i just found it, so thankyou devs thats awesome! initial rating updated from 7/10 to 8/10 and changed recommendation to yes instead of no

I bought this game within the first minute it came out and played it for 15 hours straight with out standing up out of my chair and i cant really do that with any other game out there. Now, is it a fun game? The simple answer is yes. Although i used to enjoy the game i have a lot of trouble enjoying it now. The game lacks a lot of new content, like a lot. A prime example is their updates, they take forever! The developers update the game every few months but barely bring anything to it. It took them a little over 3 months to add the new "Sewer Dealer Bro" to the main branch when all it does is add a new sewer map and a little new police mechanic that honestly doesn't make the game anymore fun than it already was. This is very frustrating when somebody like me who really, and i mean REALLY wants to enjoy the game, just cant anymore. Although im not sure if this is true but i've heard there are about 4+ developers working on this project and it pains me to say this but if that is true than this is just plain embarrassing. Either you guys lack the skill to develop (Which i dont think is the case) or you guys are just really lazy. Another thing is that the developers dont listen to the community whatsoever. They have a steam forum and even a discord server where they ask you to leave suggestions for the game but i have yet to see one single suggestion implemented into the game other than weed growing (which should have already been in the game!) and this new sewer update. To top it off i want to say this. If you are looking to buy this game only expecting about 10 hours of pure enjoyment and maybe replaying it in the far future this is the game for you. But if you are looking to have this game installed on your computer for the rest of your life expecting game changing updates, dont buy it. Once again, I LOVED the game but i just cant anymore and for that reason im leaving a negative review.

This product receives frequent hate for the 'laziness' of it's developers slow pace to add minimal content to the game however given that it is a new game that is just over 1 year old, I am willing to give it the benefit of doubt for now. So that said...

Pros / Fun Stuff
- Ordering, mixing drugs with drugs or cutting it with salt, sugar, etc
- Inventory management is reasonably easy 
- Movement and HUD is overall smooth, however HUD could do with an option to keep objectives displayed
- Managing your suspicion levels
- Supplying dealers and customers while ensuring they don't OD

Cons / Chore Stuff
- Want an option to keep objectives displayed
- Suspicion levels can easily go wildly high or low depending on how you do business
- Drug storage, jars, containers and equipment could do with more information
- Furniture storage is poor, is large compared to the small and awkward lay out of safe houses
- No end game content
- No objectives past a certain point

Suggestions
- More HUD options
- Fix furniture/wardrobes/cupboards to have better storage capacity
- Money should not take up as much space as it does
- Drugs should not take up as much space as it does
- More availability of cutting agents
- Better explanation of equipment, growing, processing, making of different drugs
- More stuff to buy and more area to explore
- More objectives
- Reputation drop needs to dramatically lower.
- Improve smoothness of movement when running

So, a few caveats before I get into my review. 1) I didn't see any of the marketing promising features that didn't end up in the game, 2) content wise, this game is still somewhat sparse. 

Those out of the way, this game is weirdly satisfying, and fun to pick up for a bit of time every so often, but you probably won't find yourself playing for long stretches of time, simply because the content is pretty repetitive, all things considered. Still though, I've definitely gotten my money's worth out of this game. The latest update brings the sewers to the game, which is a nice switch up, and gives you another way to move between the two sectors. It doesn't bring a whole lot of new content, but it's a nice change, and pretty impressive considering as far as I can tell, Byterunners is actually just one person in Poland.

If you're looking for a storyline, or deep gameplay, you're going to find it, at least not yet. If you enjoy a small, but satisfying gameplay loop, you'll probably find fun in DDS.

[b]Dear Reader![/b]

My review will split into two parts, one is about their discord server, other is about the game.

Some basic info about my past with the game:

My first encounter with the game was a trailer, that showed an action-packed game, with a lot of opportunities.
After the game has been released, I noticed this trailer disappeared from steam. I decided not to buy the game, but after months I only read positive reviews, and I loved the concept, so
 I bought the game 14th of October 2020.

I'll start my review about the things I experienced on the discord server.

The server is a playground for some moderators with a mental disorder of excessive power strivings.
 If you decide to join and say something they don't like you will get moderated, there are no guidelines or valid rules they do anything they want, you can easily be moderated for saying a criticism in a diplomatic, non-toxic way.  Verbal self-defense is useless, it will get you banned, even if facts are on your side.
Strong censorship is present on the server. Messages randomly get deleted, mostly if somebody is unhappy with the game's development. 
Warnings from the moderators often contain passive-aggressive and vulgar terms.
They allow themselves to say sexual references, and they are going to do it.

Personally, from a publisher as big as Movie Games, I would expect much more professionalism.

Movie Games, wait what?

Yes, the actual developer team has no contact with the community on Discord. The people you see with the Dev role are mostly employees of the publisher, they are just there for no reason.

Let's talk about the game.

It is enjoyable and fun for the first 10 hours, as you level up you will start to feel the emptiness. 
You will realize that you spent your precious time running around and distributing products.  It's become monotone, you will have a large amount of cash, that you can't use, because there is no proper game economy. You will endlessly wait for the next patch, that brings positive changes, but you will feel disappointed because the developers won't listen to the community.
Hundreds and thousands of suggestion have been made on how to improve the game, clever and wise suggestions I might add,
but the community's wishes found no listening ears.

It's been a very depressing experience for me. 
Sadly, I can't refund it anymore.
Please instead of buying this game, spend that money on something, like chocolate you like. You deserve it, but you don't deserve the suffering this game causes you. 

Sincerely, 

Your kindest steammate

*Sigh* Man.. I loved this game during corona-lockdown. I was working from home and alt-tabbing between my CRM and Drug Dealer Simulator. I even tried to do calls while playing. Loved it. So much potential. 

 But the developers have seemed to abandoned it. That's it. It's finished. There's a game-breaking bug where your purchased hideouts get wiped in Zone B. You can buy all the hideouts within 5 hours of dedicated playing. You could just keep going, buy a bunch of a cool things and decorate all your hideouts.. until you reload your save and they're all empty. There's no chance of this getting fixed as the devs abandoned the game once they discovered that bug. Onto new gimmicks they can get paid for before another game breaking bug appears on that one. I wouldn't support until they finish the game.

Really fun game concept, which keeps you entertained for several hours. You start small and grow pretty quick, by the time you have big drops you have more money then you could spend. In my opinion it still has much to improve especially the mid to late game, after lvl 25-30 (aprox) there isn't anything new to unlock or do.

Suggestions to devs (take 'em or leave 'em):
- MAIN SUGGESTION:  I would like to choose what neighborhoods I sell on, maybe add location of clients/dealers or a configuration in shaddyCom which allows this (like certain drugs are disabled)
- Consider adding late game unlocks/mechanics. Get enough reputation to buy off cops in checkpoints or look the other way for X time (it should be really expensive)
- Add more plants. Coca seeds to make Cocaine from scratch or poppy seeds for heroin.
- Add bigger labs (maybe for late game) with possibility to produce synthetic drugs from scratch
- Add base drug quality for more complexity, maybe with the posibility of hireing cooks with a certain skill set.
- Add more utility to pitcoin, honestly I see no need to use it right now since it's easier to pay Eddie multiple times with cash and it saves you the pitcoin conversion cost.
- Review Police. Maybe add corrupt cops that steal your stuff, take bribes to look the other way
- Add skills to your dealers and/or clients: "Seller skill" for more frequent sells, "Ninja skill" for less exposure and "Loyalty skill" this would be if the person gets caught and you have a higher chance of them not throwing the heat towards you.
- Add more risk: competitors / street thieves / informants / cameras
- More missions please. Change some unlocks to be mission based instead of just lvl based.
- Add new district that isn't as easy to smuggle but and certain rewards to do so, might need to plant drugs on a vehicle and wait a certain time to pick it up passed the checkpoint or another city and you have to plant drugs on a plan or boat, that would be awsome to see.

These are just some of the things I thought about during my playthrough, I want to end the note by saying it's a really good game with A LOT of potential, keep up the good work.

First I want to establish to the Reader that I have been a beta tester for this game by choice for almost a year so I speak from experience and from heart.

To the point: this game is a SCAM! DO NOT BUY IT! This publisher (MovieGames) specialises in creating noname shell companies which you can find literally no information about. If you do not believe me just try finding any information about this dev company  ‚ÄôByterunners Game Studio‚Äô.  I believe they do this to extort money from the publisher and have easy access to it so the game wasn‚Äôt made to be a game, it was made to be a bridge between inaccessible money and themselves. That is why this game is in this absolute sorry state and that is why the patches were so slow and crappy. They buy a few assets and use them to create the illusion that they actually do work on the game when they couldn‚Äôt give less crap about it. They make a couple of days work last for months and then sell it as hard work because they are indie company and they have just a handful of developers. Bullcrap, anyone remotely versed in unreal engine development knows that they barely touch the game.

This game was advertised borderline falsely, legally it wasn‚Äôt false advertisement but many-many customers were fed up because they felt cheated and scammed. They tried their hardest to hide it after the drama, the trailer was a blacklisted topic on their official discord, they would instantly ban you by bringing it up and hide behind the typical twisted reasons of ‚Äûcausing drama/toxicity‚Äù. But thankfully the internet doesn‚Äôt forget so it can still be found and people can draw their own conclusions for themselves: https://youtu.be/eV7j06tZzFY  For the record I personally would call this false advertisement because it was only removed AFTER a few days of the game's release.

The game is still filled with bugs which wouldn‚Äôt be an issue if they were new, but I as a beta tester experience such old bugs that were with me at launch, typos that I had reported a dozen times. Honestly how hard can it be to change a few strings in the span of an entire year? They reworked the map for no reason other than to keep up the illusion that they are working and the result caused unimaginable amount of performance issues, everyone has performance issues now, doesn‚Äôt matter how beast of a computer you have. The version that serves as a demo, called ‚Äûfree sample‚Äù can be found in the store as a free game and that doesn‚Äôt have this ‚Äûupdated‚Äù map. The demo version you can see on this storepage is not that version I am talking about, I haven‚Äôt had the ‚Äûpleasure‚Äù to try this version out because I simply cannot install it‚Ä¶ The font they are using to display the task list in game is incredibly hard to read. It actually makes me feel like I‚Äôm dyslexic because I have to concentrate to read it. I have pointed this out to the developers plenty of times and not just me, but as usual it wasn‚Äôt even dignified with acknowledgement. Can‚Äôt provide a picture as an example so I will try my best to replicate it: ‚ÄûD E L I V E R  2 G  O F  C O C A I N E  T O  O D D A R A F A L‚Äù.  Yes it is something awful like this. Every letter is capital, the space between letters and words are barely distinguishable (unfortunately steam removes the extra spaces so I can't create a perfect replica so I will have to assume that you have good enough imagination or copy paste it, put 2 or 3 spaces between the WORDS and see for yourself) It is nothing like in the videos you can see on this store page. The public roadmap which has little to no information, is literally just a picture with a few pictures that reference the milestones so it leaves you with your creativity to guess what those might be. It was abandoned for some odd reason I don't know why, but no one has been notified by that, everyone realised this fact by simply seeing the direction the developers go with this game. Such little things matter a lot because they show their undeniable attitude towards the game: they do not care about the game. This is their bread and butter and they don‚Äôt care to make the game more enjoyable or more comfortable to play it for you even after  months of begging.

I would even write a negative review on the publisher but unfortunately I can‚Äôt do that, I would advise against buying anything from MovieGames.

Well let me start by saying that, the hours i sank into this game are purely due to the logistic nature that resides in this kind of game. I like watching my $$ numbers going up while i do almost nothing. Now, let's analyze the game a bit:

1. You are a mule for the cartel. You start small, dealing small and then you get dealers that deal for you while you sit around doing nothing.
2. There are some basic mechanics here and there: A) Mixing drugs, B) Lockpicking, C) Evading Police, D) Supposedly there are DEA dogs (?) which i haven't seen anywhere, even though i saw a tip about them on the loading screen somewhere, E) Spray painting, F) Planting Weed, G) Police Raids(which i never experienced, H) Risk Factor and Exposure meters 
3. The graphics are ugly, the faces are weird and there is literaly one police officer model in the entire game.
4. Annoying voice lines, annoying music and the f******g shady comm thing that everyone complains about is still in there.
5. Actual gameplay (?): You walk around, deal drugs, evade the police, paint the walls to keep the respect high and that's about it. You end up muling cocaine for the cartel at larger quantities to gain rep. I did that. I reached the 500 rep and the game just threw me another goal. Get all the houses and areas to own the ghetto. I haven't gotten to all the areas (left one for last) and I only had like 4 of the hideouts. In the final hour of the game, i laundered some money, bought all the houses and.... nothing happened. No achievement, no call from Eddie. Nothing. My whole progress seemed so empty at that point that i realized that the game won't get any better anytime soon and that i was done with it. 
6. All the money you earn will get you nothing. You might as well plaster the windows with them since everyone that passes in front of them can see the stacks of drugs on your table.
7. The things i like about the game? The logistics. The " 100 gr of this and 120 gr of that. You take this, and you take that. Now give me my money" It's kind of fun to evade the cops in the night but that quickly turns into a nuisance if you just stay in the shadows. 
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
TL:DR & Ending sentiment: Deep as puddle and wide as a small lake. If you like numbers, the game is worth the money. You are lucky if you didn't get baited by the first trailer which had things that would never be part of this game. It feels like half an effort of a game and i doubt it will got far in matters of content.

Great game, Really fun BUT not enough.
The game is fun, at first you will be really excited and amazed at everything but after some time it just goes away, I'll explain:
1.- You have no purpose. Yes you are a dealer but other than moving drugs and avoiding the police the game doesn't has a purpose after 10-15 hours, less if you are really good.
2.- It gets repetitive. After a while you will start selling more and more drugs but it's the same in the end, it eventually feels like a "job" because you have to check the packaging, deliver the money and do all that stuff but times 10.
3.- It lacks content. It has a nice amount of content but it's still pretty shallow, there's no story, there's no development for your character, there's not map development. In short, after the 10th hour or so you'll already have seen everything the game has to offer.

I initially posted a positive review as I was enjoying the sneaking about and mixing up batches, while waiting for more features to be added ...but they have been lacking. Sure we got weed growing, but not like we were shown in the trailers. Not going to bang that drum though as plenty of other reviewers have made that point.

Ok, so why else am I now changing my review?
It's just not that fun.
Once I figured out the best routes to where you deal, those were the only parts of the level I saw.
And to repeat that "the level". One and only one level. No sneaking out to other parts of the city. No shipments to other places. Not even a sewer level. I can't believe this game made me type those words.

The quests are non optional, halt all other deals until you visit one of 2 gang leaders, and they want cocaine.
I don't sell cocaine, but does the asshat offering me this deal care? No, he wants a pile of coke asap.
However, as I have set up a dozen dealers and a few customers, all of whom are rocking my leading brand of speed called "spid" (It's an Eddie Izzard reference), all my money is tied up in deals and all my stock is amp.
I can't afford the coke I don't sell, and the dealers don't pay me back in time, so I fail the mission.
TLDR - missions are a badly coded joke.

Some people have pointed out the bugs. And there are more than a few.
I've seen windows not render, police chasing me only to do nothing when they get to me, all police congregating in one area like a doughnut convention, clipping through terrain, assets loading at the wrong scale (check out the baby dumpster screenshot I posted!) and many more to boot.

There are areas of the map that serve little to no purpose. The shanty town is deserted, the boarded up house is out of bounds, there are loads of buildings with nothing in them.

There is early access, but this is shipping the bare bones of a game.

Steer WELL clear of this one, folks. Don't get me wrong, it's fun. It really is. However the entire point of this game is to hook you to the point where you've played 2+ hours, and as such can't refund it. Then the developers win because they got your money and you can't get it back. This game is the definition of a rough gem. It's fun to play, and I've found myself mildly addicted (haha!), going back to it over and over again over the last week. This is not something I experience with a lot of games, and arguably this is all you can ask from a game. I tend to agree, which is why I'm recommending.

But good god is it messy. Everything is rough: 

- The writing. There are dozens and dozens of typos. When it's in texts it adds to the immersion. When it's in the UX, less so.
- The map design. What you can or cannot parkour off is a bit arbitrary. Prepare to get stuck against stuff pretty often, especially at night.
- The gameplay. The base gameplay loop is solid and fun, as I said. But some features make very little sense: there are two "risk" sliders, representing how visible your operation is to the authorities. They're both described in similar terms, and seem to work in the same way. Why two, then? What's the difference? Do they have different effects? Unclear. Also, reducing these meters is unintuitive: the main and most effective method is dealing at night. Note that it doesn't generate *less* visibility, which is what the in-game help implies: instead it effectively lower your *existing* visibility, meaning that you can go from enemy #1 to ghost in the machine by running around at night and dealing more drugs. A bit odd to say the least. 
- The QA: I had items duplicate in my inventory, notifications not syncing up, cops stopping the chase for no reason, all sorts of small issues. Nothing game breaking and no crashes though, so that's good.

Then there are mechanics that are a bit odd, but that I ended up liking. For example, a big feature is the ability to cut your drugs with additives, like salt, baking soda or ibuprofen. This is a cheap way to get more product, but some additives will change the properties of the drugs, making them more addictive or dangerous. But the game doesn't give you any kind of data on that. You have to experiment, making different mixes and keeping track of what seems to work (the only signals you'll get are your customer complaining if the quality is poor, if they get addicted, and if they OD or die). It's a bit disorienting (how am I supposed to know what works? Why would I ever use washing powder?), but it's actually pretty realistic (I'm guessing real world dealers don't get detailled trip reports from their users either), and it's a bold idea to put in place. I'm into it. (Also, I'm guessing all this info is available on the wikis anyway).

So yeah. It needs work, and more than new features it needs some bug fixing (and proofreading!), but the base experience is solid and the game is really fun already. Looking forward to seeing it evolve :)

This game is incredibly fun. The mechanics are simple - buy drugs, pick up drugs, sell drugs, deliver money. Eventually, you can start experimenting with recipes to cut your drugs. Now you can even grow marijuana with purchased seeds. Eventually, delivery becomes a pain in the ass, since you have way too many customers to deliver to at night. You need to balance your suspicion with delivery needs.

I definitely got my money's worth with this game. I do wish there was more leniency with recipe experimentation. I also wish they added more chemistry into the game to allow for us to produce synthetics. The story line could use some love. It's very short and repetitive as it stands, but this did not really affect how much I enjoyed the game. I believe the biggest issue is repetition. The gameplay loop grows tired after a while. There is really no goal you are working toward.

Overall, this is an 8.5/10 with room for improvement.

This is a pretty great little game! The developers made a simple, but enjoyable indie classic. The narrative and story are a little goofy, and it's certainly more funny than serious at the end of the day. That being said, the business of the game itself, and the drug dealer mechanics are very true to life. First of all, [h1]F*CK PLAYWAY[/h1].

[u][b]Secondly[/b][/u], this is one of the very few games from the cash grab PlayWay games are usually that's actually worth playing. ByteRunners did a surprisingly decent job.
Before purchasing the game through Steam, i've played nearly 60hrs outside of Steam, and have accompanied all of the Development stages from the day it released, having played the Prologue and Pre-Release Builds.
So, i have a pretty good idea of how the game has played, and what updates have solved and added.

[u][b]That said[/b][/u], where i think ByteRunners hit almost bang on was the progression. The feel you get at the start while acting as "The Cartel's" most recent addition to their Drug distribution ring, is as every little bit of cash matters but it all also disappears when Eddie asks for the Quota of all your orders. At the start you barely get profit over the Quota of your drug orders, but that little profit keeps climbing slowly along with your level in a very balanced way. At level 15/16 you surpass the 1000xp mark by making deliveries or grabbing the cash from your dealers. Every client can become a dealer if they like the product and buy regularly. That will then, net you even bigger profit. Clients and Dealers both order drugs by different names making them seem more like an actual person and not a bot (though the Client messages can get repetitive most of the time).

[u][b]The Checkpoint crossings[/b][/u] are a pretty interesting subject, since you were able to pass them by approaching the barriers, throwing your duffle bag/backpack to the other side, letting the TRAP Officer search you and grabbing the bag afterwards. This was proof that the mechanics of this game work but not quite at the same time.
This, however, was fixed (or prevented should i say) in the 26th Feb. Update, an area around the checkpoints was added in which the player is not allowed to drop or pickup any backpack which leads me to my next point.

[u][b]Even after being fully released[/b][/u], ByteRunners are still updating the game with new content which is great seeing as this game is pretty unique both in gameplay and content and has pretty good potential to expand.

[u][b]The Gameplay[/b][/u] is pretty unique and overall pretty polished, yeah the stereotypical PlayWay scripted animations are present (for example, when jumping above walls), but that's the only thing really. Textures are all pretty much new as well as the character models, and the map might have some assets from other PlayWay trash, but i haven't noticed so i cannot comment on that.

[u][b]The Soundscape[/b][/u], as a Sound Modder and Audiophile, let me tell you that the Soundscape of the Ghetto is overall pretty unique and of decent quality, various buildings have music jumping out from the windows at various volumes and different music plays from different buildings, all within the Hip Hop/Rap and Techno Genres though.
[u][b]How's the voice acting i hear you asking?[/b][/u] The Voice Acting alone is nothing special but the people they chose to do the voice overs really do suit the game's grittiness and characters. I'm kind of a fan.

I won't get into more detail, but you can grow your own and make your own mixes to sell at a bigger price or to give away as samples to addict random bystanders into becoming your clients.

Overall, it's a solid 7.5/10. I'm still having fun and i'm only halfway through the game. If it's on sale, it's worth getting.
Thanks ByteRunners and keep the updates coming.

Do I recommend this game? I'd say a very, VERY timid yes.

The game has you playing in a near-future Californian "immigrant neighbourhood" (polite term to say walled-off part of a city full of immigrants) as a, at first, low-level drug dealer, and this part of the game is actually well represented IMO.

The gameplay is focused on stealth. There are no guns, no weapons. While this may seem strange for a game about dealing drugs and doing business with cartels and the mafia, it makes sense in this game. You are an immigrant, in a state that CLEARLY doesn't want you (hence the walls to keep you in), and should one of the people in the neighbourhood starts shooting at the cops, it wouldn't take long that they'd kick in every single door in there to find the one with the gun and deport them. So, if you want a game where you can be a criminal and shoot a big gun about it, this isn't for you. Go get Payday 2.

The drug mixing aspect of the game is more elaborate than I was expecting, but voluntarily lacking information. As the ingame tutorial says, you have to go with trial and error... Or look in the steam discussion, or the wiki. But, while the game allows you to mix basically anything with anything, and as so reach some incredibly complex recipes, mixing is in no way necessary. It only allows to get more addicts from substances that aren't very addictive (namely weed, amp and ecstasy), or lower toxicity, and so reduce deaths by overdose, of more dangerous substances (like cocaine, heroin and meth). So, if you don't like trial-and-error, and if you prefer a no-brainer, either skip the mixing, stay on simple recipes, or skip the game entirely (hopefully not only for this)

The game now allows you to grow weed yourself, to sell or mix with other stuff. Problem with this is the level at which it unlocks. It unlocks only 1 level away from cocaine, with cocaine being the second to last sell-able drug available. By the time you reach it, you'll either skip growing weed, or mix it with other stuff to make it addictive.

Police raids. Yep. Police raids. Honestly, I didn't expect this one. First thing to know: your initial apartment is basically a sanctuary. No cops can come in, you cannot lose it, cannot lose the stuff in it either. Nothing bad can happen there, and if you keep away from mixing, it may end up being all that you need. Ever. But, if you get into mixing, you'll quickly run out of space. So you can buy another place, which you can customise. BUT! If you do too many deals, if you're too suspicious, you may walk by a car you never saw before, right by your new place, and walk up to a locked door. You open it, only to have a message that says "Raid in XX seconds!" And that's only the MAXIMUM time. So you pick up what you can, and jump out the window, with flashbangs and smokes going off, and you running from the cops.

And now... The cons.

First, and possibly most critical point... The communication from the dev team. Up until 2021, the communication from the devs were basically non-existent. Last news of 2020 (other than the dec 30th one) was on october 29th, for halloween. The halloween deco stayed until the January patch. Before that, it was another several months. BUT! In 2021, they actually admitted that they should have communicated more, and that there was no excuse for their silence. Since then, they released 2 updates, one in January, one in February. Maybe March will see another one, I sure hope so.

Second, and also a very requested point that the devs still haven't worked on (as far as I know) is that the story just ends at some point, with no indication as such. You start dealing with the gangs, and that's it. They will order more and more, infinitely, This may have changed in the most recent updates, I am not 100% sure, but I haven't seen it in the patch notes. Instead, they have added a third gang, this one dealing with weed. BUT this gang comes with the addition of LSD, which I still haven't tested in the game.

Finally, bugs. While they are not as common as last year, there are still a few. Also, not exactly sure at which point last year, but the textures for a lot of people went from normal to 1990's low-res. Like... Doom had better graphics. We had to wait for the halloween update for a fix, and then got stuck with the halloween deco for months!

TL;DR: I VERY cautiously recommend the game. While it is out of early access, there are still a lot of unfinished stuff, a lot of potential, and the coming months will truly determine if the devs have what it takes to make this game into the masterpiece it can be, or if it will be abandoned, like so many other early access games.

I started playing Among Us chiefly do the huge amount of requests I got from friends and viewers to check it out. And I'm glad I did. It's a great party game. It's a game where you get together with friends, and have a big WHODUNIT match, very much like an interactive board game, but better. It's a LOT of fun, when you have people to play with.

However, you have to understand that Among Us is simply that. A casual, party game meant to be played with friends. It's not a game that requires a great amount of skill, just the ability to be a detective, and see through people's lies. Or, when you are the imposter, it requires you to be an excellent liar. It's definitely a game worth playing, but it isn't a game that you should take and replace your life with.

The core gameplay loop does get boring relatively quickly, because there is nothing to work towards, nor does it have any real progression mechanics. It simply exists as a fun, round-by-round type game. Nothing more, and nothing less.

Why do I recommend against buying it? Only because the mobile version exists. The PC version is just the mobile port, but while the mobile version is free-to-play, the PC version is $5 normally, or $4 on sale.

I suggest that if you to play Among Us, that you save your money, download the BlueStacks Android emulator, and play it on there for free instead. That's what I wish I did.

I hope you found this review helpful! Please leave me a rating, and give me your thoughts in the comments, as I would love to hear feedback, ideas, and what personal experiences you've had with this title.

This game has incredible potential, however the devs seem to not update the game as frequently as possible. I bought this game the day it was made available for purchase on the steam store, finished what they had already created as the storyline. i have now come back to see that not much has changed apart from small bug fixes and a little customisation. 

PROS
- Incredibly fun and easy to learn controls and mechanics.
- Great difficulty settings, perfect for people who want a challenge.
- You are able to take many paths of which drugs to sell and not sell, using the laptop, you can 'stop selling' specific drugs and focus on a smaller group.
- Good experimentation opportunities.
- Awesome risk taking opportunities.
- Can take many pathways of your drug dealing career.

CONS
- Infrequent update cycle.
- Hard to come back to and pick up where you left off
- Unfinished story 
- Minor bugs
- Can be repetitive

Overall, a good game to buy if youre looking for 25-50 hours of playtime, a fun game, large potential for future updates. However the game feels very repetitive and sometimes feels boring as you seem to be doing the same thing day in day out.
