Appropriately addicting for as long as it takes for you to unlock all areas, drugs, and available gang missions. After that, the game becomes a pretty straightforward logistics simulator, in which you buy, adulterate, stockpile, and sell drugs as efficiently as you can. 

The game play gets pretty stagnant at this point, and I think it's pretty much impossible to have a decent reputation in more than like 3-4 zones at once without becoming significantly more visible to cops/DEA; I've never had a drug raid, but apparently that can happen if your "exposition" is too high -- I'm pretty sure the word "exposure" would be more appropriate here, but this game is absolutely RIFE with spelling and grammar errors, which I find kind of ridiculous for how long it's been in development. Having no experience in game design, I assumed spelling errors would probably be the single easiest thing to fix, but apparently that is either not the case, or the devs of this game just straight up don't want to bother. It doesn't necessarily interfere with game play too much, but it makes you wonder why you spent $20 on this game every time you check how many "dolars" you have in your inventory. 

All that said, I frequently found myself checking the time while playing this and thinking "holy shit how is it 2:30 am already?". Much like a traditional drug addiction, this game is capable of consuming A LOT of your time if you let it. If you enjoy simulator games and want to experience what it's like to be a low-rent El Chapo, I would recommend picking this up on sale. The sense of progression is good while it lasts, and the options for mixing and adulterating drugs is surprisingly fun to experiment with, although slightly janky at times. Just remember that you will probably (and most likely suddenly) reach a point at which you will lose interest, as there is no end game I have found (this is a simulator, after all).

The biggest problem with the game is the lack of direction in the development. They have a good early game, but no end game, and no indication that any endgame style content is being worked on, or even planned.

Instead, updates consist of adding more drugs, even though the ones we have are sufficent to make more money than can be spent. Or arbitrary changes to systems that don't need to be changed, like the pack system. This is stuff you tweak after the main game's done, not before adding end game content.

Sadly, the combination of mostly positive reviews, lack of EA status, and the random acts of development says to me that we'll probably never see this game reach a state of feature completeness. Financially, I'm sure it's been a success for the devs and publisher, but will probably remain kind of a let down for players who played for more than a few hours.

It's one of those situations where we can all see the game has almost limitless potential, but probably won't ever come close to reaching it.

Even though the early game's great, the total lack of end game content is the reason I'm giving this one a thumbs down. Sorry, but I can't recommend half a game.

Drug Dealer Simulator is a criminally underrated game that you should give a try if you like what you read in this review. You start off selling weed and amphetamine to a couple of people, but you slowly make your way up the ranks until you start selling harsher drugs like meth, coke, and fentanyl. As you progress in the game you'll buy new warehouses, equipment, and furniture. All have their uses. For example, you should split your product and move it to different warehouses so if you get raided by the DEA you won't lose everything. DDS isn't your average game, you ALWAYS have to think ahead and keep on your toes to prevent raids, loss of area respect, and the time limit for providing product for gangs later in the game. If everything you just read seems appealing to you, I would 100% recommend trying out this game.

Way more fun and engaging than I originally thought it would be. Other than there needing to be more content, my only other complaint is with the police. Completely broken. Either oblivious to the point of absurdity, or they're regularly tazing me inside my hideouts despite me being away from the door and the door itself being closed. Also an issue with the border police regularly searching you twice within seconds of the last search while passing through the wall. Along with the way that they respond to your character running, if they decide to search you while you're passing by in mid-sprint you're completely fucked. For whatever reason the game decided that running, period, during any stage of the search results in an immediate chase and taze. Not a HUGE problem when there's only two groups patrolling, but later in the game when you're gonna have typically several groups patrolling it becomes a massive problem. When even a trip to the ATM results in every single police crew in the area going after you because one of them decided they wanted to randomly search you while you're trying to sprint to your destination. Even better when you're trying to mule drugs between your hideouts when it happens, causing you not only a fine but also losing all the product you had on you, and potentially pissing off any customers who were waiting on you if you were delivering. Also, the mix quality needs to be made more user-friendly. I can get the realism aspect, but inadvertently pissing off a gang or your customers with low quality mixes, or even inadvertently killing them, because you have absolutely zero way to verify quality even though every gang and customer has quality demands, doesn't make any sense. Along with potentially having you accidentally waste a significant amount of pure product. I also see there are several mixes I found online that require MJ to be used in them, the problem though is there is absolutely zero way to incorporate it in any form in any mix because none of the equipment accepts it except the liquid trays and dryers, which is fine and well but the result can't be used in any mixer or miller because none of them accept plant matter. 

Add more content. Fix the police. They're useless at best and an absolutely pointless nuisance at worst. If MJ needs to be used in certain mixes make it so we can actually USE it in mixes in that case. And have some way or form of at least being able to tell if the quality of a mix is acceptable, preferably with a way to tell strength and toxicity as well seeing how they're so important to the mix and the results. 3 stars for now, if those problems are ever fixed then it's a definite 5 stars

I am completely re-doing this review as my original was at launch. Since then the game has changed in significant ways and content. 

DDS is an interesting twist on the 'time killer' genre of repeating tasks millions of times but keeping it fun all the while. 
The game has seen a bunch of added content since launch, but still suffers from some of the balancing issues present since then as well. 
There is now a bit more storyline and gang activity is increased, however it's still fairly short lived with limited rewards for the effort. But it breaks up the routine of ordering, cutting, packaging, and delivering that becomes your life in DDS. 
The map is still pretty small which is great for making door dashes a breeze, but with only a few streets and active buildings in the game, you will get fairly tired of the same route around the map. As you progress in skills and open a couple new hideouts, simply running from the cops becomes easier than stealth. It does raise your suspicion level but for most of the game it matters very little. For the most part just running around saves time and you are no worse for it than sneaking about. 
Unlocking new drugs and items is a nice progression but a bit unbalanced. By the time you can grow weed, it's likely you are not even selling it anymore. Also, you grow so much weed with a small space that a couple indoor plants or a few outdoor ones is all you'll ever need. Expanding to a gigantic pot operation doesn't really pay off since you don't become the cartel's pot supplier. 
Other drugs like Ecstasy also unlocks around the time that once you have all the gear needed to cut it and put it back in pill form- it's not a profitable product anyway. Fun for RP reasons or just to play mad scientist with mixes, but it's pretty much going out of your way to bother with it. Only Cocaine and Meth matter for the gang content. Heroin comes late but is one of the best drugs for getting addicts. 
The game has several interesting concepts in play. One being that getting addicts is good as they order larger amounts but bad in that they tend to die from OD which hurts your reputation. Many people create a different mix for before and after a client becomes addicted. Some of your clients will offer to be dealers under you, which is a big step up in sales but adds a second meeting to later collect money. You can rent (it's actually a one time purchase) hideouts around town to move operations to, use to hide from cops, and save the game from. Each of these further increases reputation or adds clients to the pool. However each area is increasingly more difficult to access. 
There is some weirdness in packaging amounts and losing some product to processing. So after processing loss you may have fractions of a gram left over- but no way to package anything under 1g nor with any fraction attached. In some lab gear you will have to 'dump' the excess to use the equipment again-- meaning losing some small amount each time. It's just a clunky system. 
Police searches are constant, which is why I say it's just easier to skill up running and stamina, and just run from the cops. Police can sniff you out from long distances sometimes, and other times I run full sprint right past them and they don't notice me. Stealth seems a bit broken, but hoofin' it works every time. 
The game is great for those that want to play Walter White and mix up custom batches of drugs. There are online guides for the hard numbers. There is an element of RNG though, so you can still see OD's from 'safe' mixes found in guides. There is a selection of furniture and lab gear but for the most part you don't need to have labs all over the place. The map is small enough that you can operate from basically two HQ buildings, one on each side of the wall and mandatory police searches. I recommend using single floor rentals because running up and down stairs takes a ton of your time. 
You need to be able to listen for police radios so you don't stumble around a corner into a patrol, but otherwise there isn't much to listen to in the game. Voice acting is good, but very sparse. 
Not much replayability value except to run for different gang content, but the core of the game is repetitious enough, other than for RP purposes, there isn't much fun in re-playing those early levels. 
I have a ton of fun with this game. It's expanding so there is much more to do now than when it launched. Hope it keeps getting love.

Alright. I cannot understand why people post nonsense as a review... We all love MJ but we can really help with a normal review... PFFF! Kids! 

‚ñ∫ Now for a Normal Review...

First off i would like to state that i found out about the game from a YT video, i downloaded the demo, got fixated and then bought the game.

Now, let's make clear that this game is -in my opinion- still on development and that is something really good considering what we have and the potential of it!

We are talking about a First Person Perspective Drug Dealer Simulator as the title states and it is really fun to play. If you like it, it gets you feeling that you exist as the game character and you have to deliver the goods on time to benefit of a good rating by the clients.

‚ñ∫ Game starts and then...

You wake up in your apartment after you got fired from your job and get a phone call from Eddie. The guy that is your connection with the cartel. You get to meet up with him and he gives you the basics of the game.

After that the learning begins.

The game does a really good job on teaching you what to do in the begining, and to get you going by giving you tasks to complete just to unlock drugs and neighborhoods to sell products. 

As the game progresses, you can rent multiple apartments to use as stash places and secondary bases just to avoid getting caught on a neighborhood with loads of stuff on you going on a delivery.

You have to constantly be in the move and organize a lot, just to start making money. The catch is that you have to push product not only on the daylight hours, but more at night without getting caught by the police. If you move in the morning your Drug Dealer wanted status is going to bring more police in the areas that you are selling, risking more searches, more difficult movement between parts of the town and the worst... a DEA raid. So time management and careful planing of your moves is really essential.

That game even got me anxious as i was moving product at night during "Police Hours" that normally citizens are prohibited from circulation. Something like the quarantine limitations!!!

Also after you get the basics you can mix random ingredients that you are buying on shops with the drugs to "cook" them and get more profit!

In my opinion it is a really good game that with our help the developer(s) can polish and bring more and more things in it! For example, sleeping schedule, better neighborhood design, some "hidden" perks to have the knowledge on mixing and baking, the potential of the player growing plants to create something, e.g. MJ, normal prices on the sales (e.g. 25 bucks for a spray can???) etc...

The game is really good, stable without any glitches that i have experienced. I hope that the devs are going to continue creating!

P.S. For the guy that wrote a review about the game not working.... Dude... Learn how to use PCs... Just Saying!

Alrighty y'all. 
I've had this game since it came out essentially.  Watched the first couple of live streams too.

When the game launched, you could play it, sure, but it got tedious and buggy. 
There was suspicion that this was done on purpose as to release an almost finished game and buy time to develop content.
The end result is probably a little of A and B.

But check it out, the game runs reasonable FPS now and I think I have had one CTD instead of GB-bugs every hour or so. 
The game play progression is filled with new features for quite a while now, instead of having three or four major gaps between features, it seems the biggest one is for this new gang feature @ 500 respect.

Cannabis growing is finally in, and I'm glad they didn't try to push it while it was broken. 

Eh.. TLDR: if the current version (1.07 I think) was 1.0 there would be hardly a negative review.

fun game at the beginning, very boring at the end. First 20-40 hours are great. You have a lot to experiment with, optimize and make your routes better, enjoy running away from police officers. But once you reached a certain level, there is nothing apart from a running simulator. Police is very easy to outrun once you reached a certain stamina and speed levels, interaction with the clients is very scarce (again, no content). Same locations, music is the same in the buildings it is coming from (again, no content). 

You can experiment with different mixtures but community website managed to break the meta at early stages which makes your game at maximum efficiency with little or no thinking, unless you want to invent a bike (again, no content). 

I see little point responding to buyers unless they are dealers with huge requests as it makes little or no money for you but you have to mix drugs a lot. 

Only if you want to make a picture of how much stuff you have and show off, you can enjoy this game as long as you want but as continuous experience - boring as hell.

I love this game. It does have some bugs, not totally game ruining in my opinion like some people say, but it does have some that can be a pain. I save in 3 different slots and save often for that reason. But honestly I have not run into any glitches in over a month so they may have fixed most if not all of them. This game has something about it that just makes it addicting. The overall simplicity combined with the fun factor of this game makes it one of the best games in my catalog and I regularly look for additional content to purchase for this game and wait in anticipation. I definitely recommend picking this game up for yourself if your looking for something that is not too complicated and easy to play, put down, then pick back up again time after time. If there is anything about this game that kind of gets to me is the misspelling. I'm not sure if its on purpose because of the context of the game, or if its because the devs are speeding through too much but that would be my only complaint and even that is a very small issue to me. If your looking for something simple and cheap that you can spend 100 hours on then pick this up. I promise you wont regret it.

I find this game to be fun and humorous. It presents plenty of challenges as well as a fun and detailed map with a number of great songs that are now on my spotify playlist. It is also interesting getting high on coke and getting $4000 worth of heroin stolen from me by the DEA. The only two things I really have against this game is that there are a few annoying glitches and even if you have the latest, greatest and most powerful GPU on the market, you will still only be able to run a max of 30fps on full graphics. Because all I have is a GeForce GTS 450 and an Intel Core 2 Quad (please don't judge me :P), I can only get playable frame rates at potato quality graphics. Other than that, me and one of my friends have gotten huge amounts of fun out of this game being able to do illegal things without the police on us. I would rate it 4.5 out of 5 stars.

Edit: I got a new GPU (RTX 2060) and CPU (Intel i5 10th gen) so the game runs way better. It also helps that the 'Harty Pard' update reduces impact on hardware, meaning that my Acer Nitro 5 won't explode every time I play. Thanks Byterunners, you're the best lol.

I had a feeling that this was going to be another unity-engine, Polish-made, Goat-Simulator-style joke Steam game that's just in it for the memes. Whereas, it does seem remarkably Polish: this is a real game, and real effort was put into it. 

The gameplay mechanics do a good job of replicating what I assume dealers would have to problem-solve. Quickly measuring out the right amounts of product into the right number of bags, avoiding paper trails by only using cash and laundering your ATM transactions, and even anticipating losing yields during chemistry, if you start manufacturing. 

The developers care about this game, you can tell. The voice acting is actually decent, there are splash images and a leveling/difficulty progression that was carefully tuned, and I haven't seen any real bugs. I will say, that the translation has some oofs: almost every line has a typo or a misspelled word.

Solid game if you wanna try it out. You start small and work up, it's a neat challenge so far.
Psss... Wanna buy some drugs?

I picked this game up for ¬£10 and thief simulator for ¬£6. So i felt i got a good deal for the price.

Now let me get started, this game is low quality for the price they normally ask for.

Low quality textures, small map, repetetive gameplay and poor UI & optimisation.

Often there's spelling mistakes in loading screen tips, subtitles and general dialogue.

The police seem to already know where you are and think 10 steps ahead of you, so be prepared to get arrested a lot. If you're lucky then throw your backpack and even if the police are right behind you they'll ignore it.... A bag full of drugs.... so you can go back and pick it up after.

The premise is dealing drugs, theres a reasonably good marketing aspect to the game. Controlling the price you sell, using perks to get better prices etc etc.

To progress properly you really need to grind hard in the game and in such a small map this really makes the gameplay boring.

Even being out during "police hours" at night (a lockdown time where if you're out you get arrested) isn't exciting. You dont feel compelled to take the risk as there's very little reward in terms of xp.

The game is fun though. i spent three hours on it from the moment i downloaded it and its fun. It feels clunky in parts and the UI for mixing drugs etc needs a lot of work which i doubt it'll get.

But if you seriously want to buy this, don't spend more than ¬£6 on it. It isn't worth your money if you're paying more than that. 

There's some funny dialogue with in jokes about other games the devs have worked on like thief simulator and that was surprising. The narrator is very well scripted and you do learn a fair bit about getting everything up and running and what it takes to run a drug business.

Overall its a standard game with low resolution physics, repetetive gameplay and poor effort in quality of mechanics and variation of gameplay.

But there's something loveable about it. i stll go onto it and play every now and then. accept drug orders, pick up the dead drops and pay the cartel my debts.

It isn't a bad game but its not worth more than ¬£6 of your money.

The game itself is fun, but it runs like literal shit

My first problem is that when i tried it for free on an old laptop in the summer it delivered the same experience in terms of fps. Its ridiculous. The hardware you need to run it is just a joke compared to how the game looks like.

Graphics settings make no difference AT ALL. The game doesnt look very different on full low settings. No matter how low it is, i dont get a much higher fps either.

Another problem is that you cannot save in the first 30 minutes. After 3 deliveries all my progress was lost because i restarted the game to change the graphics settings.

This game is not optimazed at all but it does deliver a nice experience. 
I wouldn't recommend it so far because it just doesn't feel like a finished game.

Great very addictive game with an absolutely busted progression system. You play the roll of a drug dealer, gradually building your network of clients and even other dealers to sell throughout the city. You unlock a variety of drugs and ways to mix them as time goes on to create more addictive or potent blends. 

(Spoilers below)

Progression is absolutely bizarre and needs to be redone. You start the game with Weed and Amphetamines and quickly unlock meth and Ecstasy in early game. Heres the issue, you can only mix amphetamines early on, you need expensive equipment that you unlock hours later to mix the others. So you might as well only sell amphetamine until mid game because with mixing you can up your margins 20-30%. Even worse you unlock the advanced machinery right around the time you unlock cocaine. Cocaine has insane margins and is easily mixed, at that point in the game there is no reason to sell anything else. Late game you unlock the ability to grow weed, which is cool but why would you ever want to go back to weed when you are already printing money with cocaine. So a pro tip to deal with the awful balance, make yourself stock and sell every drug, this way the economy won't be trivially easy. With all that said i do still recommend it, it is very fun even if a bit too easy.
Most accurate drug dealer sim on the market
